text:
Lets make this great recipe even easier. Cook the onions and garlic in a big, thick bottomed pan, add the chicken (chopped small or used cooked chicken that comes in the little pouch).Add dry spices and herbs. When chicken is not pink anymore and the rest of the canned ingredients. 1 can of tomato is plenty, the best corn is of the frozen kind. Top with the sourcream, tortilla chips , cheese or whatever else your heart desires! 
If this is useful-remember to mark it!

text:
The great thing about this recipe is its flexibility.  You can adjust about any quantity to your liking and still enjoy the basic flavors.  For those who thought it too bland or too spicy, the solution is to adjust your seasonings as you go.  The parsley flakes, onion powder and garlic powder are not so critical, but save adding chili powder and salt for the last, especially because the boullion cubes will be salty.  Chili powder intensifies the perception of saltiness, so add it before any salt.  Start with half the recipe quantity of spices, wait 5-10 minutes as the soup simmers for the spice flavor to fully release, then taste.  Repeat this adjustment cycle as necessary until you're satisfied.

We save the sour cream to add at the table, along with shredded cheddar cheese and corn tortilla chips.  Want great tortilla chips?  Buy a package of fresh corn tortillas.  Spray or brush both sides with olive oil, cut each tortilla in half and then julienne them into 1/4" strips.  Spread the strips out on a nonstick cookie sheet.  If you like, sprinkle with sea salt, chili powder and/or cumin.  Bake 5 minutes at 425 degrees and check; sample and bake longer until the chips achieve your desired crispness.  The julienned chips are great because they're easy to pick up with a soup spoon.  You'll never go back to store-bought chips!

text:
Wow is all I can say. Made this for the 1st time last night and my husband and I both agree it was delicious.  I decided to halve the recipe because I only needed to feed 2 adults and one child and even halfing it left us with plenty of leftovers for another meal.  I did decide to do this in the crockpot though. Here is what I did based off of other suggestions:  

Minus olive oil, corn and beans, threw everything in my crockpot (chicken breasts whole) and set on low for 8 hours.  Last 2 hours, I removed chicken breasts to shred (didn't take much as they fell apart from being in the juices), added chicken meat back in, 1 can of black beans (rinsed and drained), and the corn.  I did not use chili beans, whole tomatoes or sour cream as I prefer a lower in fat and calorie meal.  I did use a fresh pico de gallo from the store instead of canned salsa and used fire roasted diced tomatoes.  I topped our bowls with diced avocado and chopped cilantro and voila!  For the kids I added crushed fritos and cheese, the soup was not too spicy for my 3 year old.  So easy in the crockpot, I highly suggest making it this way.  So much flavor, and I will definitely be adding this to the rounds with no changes.

text:
Excellent recipe, and this is how I make it easier on myself. I use a supermarket rotisserie chicken with the skin removed and shredded off the bone. I saute the garlic and onion in the olive oil and then stir in a little flour to absorb the oil. Then I stir in 2 large containers of good quality chicken stock, and add the shredded chicken. I also use the diced tomatoes with the chiles already in them, and I double the amount and omit the whole tomatoes and tomato soup.  I use a  medium salsa that has black beans and corn already in it too. I also hold off on the sour cream and let each person top their own bowl with corn chips, sour cream, green onions and shredded cheese. Especially good cabin recipe, winter or summer.  Yum!

text:
I really liked this, but like others, I made changes: I left out the whole tomatoes and chili beans; used frozen corn rather than canned and tub of fresh salsa rather than jarred; I didn't have the patience to shred all the chicken, so I diced about half of it and it all broke up just fine; I spooned the sour cream on top of the serving bowls (good without, too) with sliced black olives--all yummy options! This definitely eats like a meal, but you can decrease the chicken if you're just looking for a side dish. Also, it freezes well. Everybody else may already know this, but I accidentally discovered that condensed tomato soup does a GREAT job cleaning electric stove elements and underpans. Those little discs in the middle of the elements are supposed to be silver! News to me!

WOW! WOW! AND WOW!  This was the BEST soup I have ever made.  It's the perfect blend of spice and  thickness, and it's FABULOUS.  

My one suggestion is if you are health conscious replace the sour cream with plain fat free yogurt.  In my opinion plain fat free yogurt tastes very close to sour cream when mixed in with things and it will save you alot of fat and calories!! 

Again, this was a great recipe!! :)

text:
I LOVED this recipe!
I've been trying to eat meals with low to no fat and came across this one.
I love spicy food so this was right up my alley.
I substituted the tomatoes for a can of Rotel diced tomatoes with green chiles like Lucky0372 did and black beans for the chili beans. PERFECT.

Another thing, I just boiled the chicken for about 20 minutes, took all but 2 quarts water from the pot, then threw everything in and simmered for an hour. It was PERFECT.
Very spicy! My husband and I sat on the couch eating the soup with a box of tissues in between us for our runny noses from the spice-lol!

I've made this 4 times already and have only had the recipe for a few weeks. For me to make a meal more than once over that time is very rare, so it HAS to be good.
I'll be serving this soup to my grandchildren! (Well, I may have to cut down on the spice for them-but I'm keeping it as is for me!

text:
This soup has become a staple in our house, by far the best soup I ever tasted. We just had a birthday party for my son and we made this soup along with other foods, everyone left with the recipe as they truly loved it. I gave some to my neighbor & he asked for the recipe saying its the best soup in the world. When I make a dish I follow the recipe exactly the first time & make any changes the second time as I see fit. I can say I only made a 3 changes, one was by accident, we forgot the sour cream & I have to admit I didn't notice any difference so to save on unnecessary fat and calories we omit it from now on. I also omit the corn, first I don't notice it in the taste nor feel it adds anything but unnecessary carbs and calories. One other change I make is I add about 1/2 tsp of Ground Red (Cayenne) Pepper. This make a huge difference in kicking it up just a bit, if 1/2 if too much try 1/4 tsp but I suggest adding it if you like a little extra spice is all. It doesn't make it hot but it will clear your sinus's out... This soup has helped me lose weight as I have been cutting fat & calories in my diet so I eat a lot of this soup as it has a lot of fiber, low in fat and low in calories. Since I write down everything I eat and keep track of my caloric intake here are the nutritional changes should you omit the corn & sour cream. 199.4 cal. 1.5g Fat, 25.7g Carbs, 23.4g Protein 7.6g Fiber per serving. Enjoy...

text:
This is a great recipe!  I usually head straight for the 5 star rated recipes and, to do them justice, follow them to a “T” on the first go around. I’m no expert chef but I have been cooking for family and friends since I was 9 yrs old and as a California born and raised “Span-Mex-Rican” who’s been around Hispanic home cooking all her life, I’ve learned a thing or two about spicy cooking. I made some changes right out of the starting gate on this one. 

Omit the ½ Teaspoon salt – there’s plenty of flavoring (and sodium) in the bouillon
Use 4 cubes of chicken bouillon (1 less than original recipe)
Use 4 cloves of garlic (1 more than original recipe)
Replace 2 (14.5 oz.) cans of peeled and diced tomatoes w/ 2 (10oz.) cans of “Ro-Tel Diced Tomatoes w/ Lime Juice & Cilantro”
Omit the 1 (14.5 oz.) can whole peeled tomatoes all together
Replace the 1 (10 oz.) can of condensed tomato soup w/ 1 (7.75 oz. can of “El Pato” – Mexican hot style tomato sauce)
Replace the canned corn w/ 2 cups of frozen corn

For the Salsa: I used “La Victoria Medium”
For the Chile Beans: I used S&W Chile Beans (Pinto Beans, Chili Pepper, Onion, Garlic in Zesty Tomato sauce)

Cook as directed except: add Chile Beans before the corn & “lightly” mash the tomatoes and beans in the pot. (This further releases the flavors of the beans & tomatoes into the broth and the smashed beans make for a creamier consistency…I’m not a big fan of whole beans or chunky tomato bits in my soup.) Then add all other ingredients

text:
I made this last night for dinner and everyone really liked it. It is a very decent soup! We made a few slight changes though. I cut out the tomato soup and only used 1 large jar of salsa and 1 can of peeled and diced tomatoes. It was PLENTY of tomato for this recipe. You do not need more! I did not have any chili powder at home, so I used a Piri Piri spice mix which was perfect. In it was dried Bird's Eye chili, onion, paprika, sea salt, pepper, garlic, and cow's parsley. I cut out the extra onion and garlic powder, but I went ahead and added the fresh garlic, onion, and additional dried parsley. I used 3 teaspoons of the Piri Piri and 2 teaspoons of Cayenne Pepper. My husband and oldest daughter wanted the soup spicier, but my youngest daughter and I thought the soup had just the right amount of heat. The canned tomatoes were far too acidic tasting, so I also added a teaspoon of sugar as well. Then it was perfect!
I couldn't find Chili beans, but a can of kidney beans and a can of white beans worked just fine. The sour cream was served at the table for each person to add to the soup themselves. I found that the serving size was absolutely correct. I have enough leftovers for all four of us to eat another bowl. I froze it for later use. Everyone agreed that the soup should get 4 stars. It was delicious. The only request I had was less chicken and more beans next time! Of course, this is a personal preference. Thank you for the wonderful recipe!

text:
I have made this "soup" many times and each time i make changes to the original recipe. This time i wanted to make it less salty and lighter tasting while keeping the spice and heat.   I used 6 chicken breasts and that was more than enough.  I  substituted low sodium chicken broth for the bouillon cubes and added 1 bay leaf and cooked the chicken per the instructions and in 40 minutes the chicken was 165.  Next i chopped up 1 green pepper, 1 red pepper, 1 poblano pepper, 1 serrano pepper and 2 jalapeno peppers. I sauteed 1 jalapeno with the onions and garlic then threw the rest of the peppers in with the soup. The peppers gave the soup some nice color along with the heat. The heat will mellow overnight in the fridge if you're making it for the next day. I left out the  the sour cream and the can of whole tomatoes, used 1/2 the chili powder and substituted "No Salt Added" diced tomatoes for the regular diced tomatoes. Also, i blew off the corn this time but i use frozen when i use it.  The soup had a nice lite, spicy flavor without too much salt. This would be good in summer with some cilantro, a little lime juice and a margarita.

text:
Definitely a keeper. Nothing to knock you out of your chair, but darn good and with so many ingredients that you can keep on hand, it's a real go-to recipe. Used drumsticks instead of breasts. Replaced the can of whole tomatoes with another can of diced (think next time I'll omit one of the cans. it was very tomato heavy). Left out the soup, seeing how tomato-y it was. Added a can of hominy and replaced a can of chili beans with black beans. Didn't drain the corn (because corn is soooo tasty!). choose a good chunky salsa because it imparts a lot of great flavor to this. Put the sour cream as a dollop on each bowl, instead of mixing it in.

text:
I really wanted to try this recipe, but didn't have a lot of time, so I used a crock pot. I followed the recipe as it pertains to measurement of ingredients, but modified the steps a bit for the crock pot timing. As the chicken, water, salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, parsley and bouillon cubes were cooking in the pot (kept it on low setting), I prepared the second half of the recipe. 
After combining the sauteed onions and garlic with all of the good stuff (minus chili beans and sour cream), I just removed a bit of the broth from the crock pot and added everything else in, except the sour cream and chili beans. After 10 hours on low, and getting up to a fresh batch of soup the next morning, I shredded the chicken (basically falls apart anyway), added the sour cream, and chili beans. It is VERY good and super easy to make, especially using a crock pot!

text:
Being lovers of both white and dark meat chicken, I cooked a whole chicken subbing fresh parsley for the dried (I think dried parsley is vile stuff, and I always have fresh in my fridge).  I used better than bouillon base instead of cubes, and thought the chicken came out great; I would use this method to cook chicken for salads or some other use.  I wanted a soup, not a chili, so I used more of the broth in the soup, and used frozen corn.  I skipped the whole tomatoes and used three jars of petite diced but my finicky teen thought it was "too tomatoey".  Next time I will use two cans of crushed and one diced and she won't know the diff.  I tasted it at the end, liked it as it was, so I skipped the sour cream, although I did put a dollop on the leftovers and it was good.  Oh, and I threw in a chipotle pepper in adobo sauce that had been hanging around my fridge for a while. I will make this soup again...Excellent!

THIS IS AN AMAZING SOUP! Reminds me of chicken tortilla. Very easy to make. I like spicy food (not too spicy though) but after reading the ingredients, I was unsure how spicy this would be. text:
I tried to emulate this recipe exactly but the day I decided to make it, realized I didn't have the ingredients precisely.  Had a couple jars of almost half-full salsas of two different brands and swapped one of the cans of chili beans for a can of black beans, only had one can of diced tomatoes and added twice the amount of chili powder called for.  Somehow, is still turned out phenomenal and I've never heard people speak so highly of my cooking before.  Thanks for an awesome base for many more great soup ideas!

Also, I didn't want the chicken to overwhelm the broth so I only used four breasts and so glad I did!

text:
This was EXCELLENT!  I used Lasvegas00's review as a guideline for cooking this in the crockpot, and it came out great.  I added a little extra corn, and a little extra light sour cream, and used black beans instead of chili beans, but kept everything else the same.
My only beef with this recipe is that the serving information seems way off base.  I made this for myself only (since no one else likes spicy food), and figured I could take it to lunch for a few days this week.  So I halved the recipe, which should have been 4 servings, but I have well over 8 LARGE servings of soup. I'm not sure how I'm going to eat it all, and wish I hadn't "wasted" all the chicken.  Next time I will cut it in 1/4 for 4 servings.  I should have known something looked off when the original 8-serving recipe called for EIGHT chicken breast halves... that is a TON of soup!
Totally delicious, though :)

text:
This was good.  For ease and to save time I bought a rotisserie chicken from the store and shredded it, then just started with a base of onion and garlic sauteed in oil and added the rest of the ingredients.  I would omit the tomato soup next time.  There is already an incredible amount of tomatoes in this recipe and adding that gave it a flavor of, obviously, condensed tomato soup, which I felt took away from the flavor of the other ingredients, which went well together.  I also used chicken broth in place of the water and bouillon.

text:
YUMMMY!!! I actually adjust this recipe as a nacho dip. I use all of the recipe, except use a HOT salsa and replace the whole peeled tomatoes with one 10oz can of HOT Rotel diced tomatoes with habaneros. So its not so soupy, I use about 2-3 cups of broth and drain everything. Its really not that hot either, it has a really nice kick. Serve as a dip with shredded cheese on top and tortillas. (-:

AUD08

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/330097.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this soup- though I think the boiling the chicken step is unnecessary. Whenever making chicken soup, I just buy a rotisserie chicken from the store, shred it, and use the carcass to make stock. This way, you can just sautee the onions, garlic, and whatever else (I like to add 1 green pepper), add the canned ingredients (buy spicy salsa if you like it spicy, mild if you don't), bring that to a simmer for half an hour, then add chicken and bring to simmer again until it's ready to eat. Season with salt and pepper to taste, stir in a spoonful of sour cream and top with tortilla chips.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/374435.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow this was really good. I basically used it as a starter and added/changed some things. I followed the same directions for making the broth, but instead I used 5 skinless, boneless chicken breast halves and it seemed like plenty. This is where I changed it. In a saucepan I added the olive oil, garlic and onions. I omitted the salsa and instead added chopped celery and carrots. While that was cooking, I shredded the chicken and reserved all the broth. To the garlic and onions I added 2 cans of peeled and diced tomatoes, the shredded chicken and ALL the remaining broth (I had about 6-7 cups. I actually omitted the rest of the ingredients and added a half of cup of rice. I let it simmer all together for about 45 minutes. Really amazing.

text:
This was "pretty good." Considering I basically live in the heart of the southwest (New Mexico) and eat spicy soups quite often (mmm, menudo), I'll try to be fair. I made this for my boyfriends family, following the recipe to a T. They said it was, "good." But I could tell that they weren't as impressed as they usually are with my food. Perhaps this would taste good to people up North. But, IMO - I wouldn't make it again, and I'm sending the leftovers to my mother to deal with, as there are plenty :P Makes more than 8 servings!

text:
Great stuff!  The only things I did to it were my typical little personal tweaks like pureeing tomatoes since I don't like the hunks, but that doesn't change the flavor any.  (Meaning, in fact, I just used all whole tomatoes.)  But all the spices, beans, etc. I did as is.  I cooked the chicken originally in the crock since that's the easiest way to shred chicken, something I dislike doing.  (And seem to do a lot anyway.)  After that I transferred to my Dutch oven which fits more easily in the fridge.  A good thing since there was plenty.  I halved the recipe and I doubt the whole thing would've fit in the Dutch oven.  This is easily at least 12 servings for the whole recipe, and I'm one who thinks a serving is a good big bowlful.  I like the level of spiciness just fine.  It was much like a tortilla soup.  Blopped on some extra sour cream on top.  I do have one issue, however: the prep time.  It's like the first step doesn't exist, so if you think you're going to start this recipe and have it ready in 45 minutes like it says, think again.  It doesn't say "cooked" chicken in the ingredients, so step 1 absolutely counts!!

text:
Quick, easy and absolutely delicious!  As I am sure many others have done, I made a few tweaks to this recipe to suit my own tastes, and it is absolutely incredible.

In order to make this recipe less labor-intensive, I made it in a crock pot and let it cook throughout the day.  Rather than sautéeing the onion and garlic, I just threw it all into the pot to cook.

Tomato paste was substituted for the condensed tomato soup, as I don't like all of the ingredients I see on the label.  I also chose to leave out the sour cream (although I'm sure it would be delicious).

The verdict: a wonderful recipe that can be manipulated to your tastes and still turn out delicious!

text:
This was an excellent recipe.  I halved it since there are only 2 of us, but we still had a lot left over.  I left out the whole tomatoes per other reviews, and changed the order of things so that I only messed up one pot.  I sauteed the onion and garlic in a large soup pot, added in the chicken to brown, then added the spices and stock.  Per other reviews I only put in chili powder to taste (and ended up not using the full amount - it was still hot).  Brought it to a simmer for 30 minutes  and then added the rest of the ingredients (no sour cream) and let it simmer for 30 minutes, breaking up the chicken (instead of taking out and shredding it). Served with grated cheddar and crushed tortilla chips.  It was excellent.

text:
Very good soup, but I didn't give it 5 stars because from experience, after simmering the chicken for 1 hour, you have nothing but dried up shreds of meat.  I  simplified the recipe by skipping the 1 hour of simmering.  I started by sauteing the onion, garlic, etc.  Then added the water, chicken bouillon, and spices, and when the water boiled, dropped in cubed chicken breasts.  25 minutes later the soup was done!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe. I modified based on prior reviews to make it a clean recipe. Halved it and it still made a lot. I used 4 frozen grilled chicken breasts and about 8 oz frozen grilled salsa which we always keep on hand. Started with the onions and garlic per the recipe, added 2.5 cups of boiled water with 3 chicken bullion cubes dissolved (microwave), salsa, 1 can petite diced tomatoes, 1 can fire roasted diced tomatoes, 1 can corn, 1 can black beans, and 1/2 can condensed tomato soup. Then added the spices used in the chicken broth, also halved. Once it was combined well, I added the frozen chicken breasts and let it simmer covered on the stove for about 30 minutes. Then I took out the chicken breasts, shredded them and added them back to the pot and let it cook about 5-10 minutes more. Wonderful!

Display Name:

isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always make a highly rated recipe as written first. The first time I made as is there was just way too much tomato for our liking and I felt like it was good but missing something.
The second time I made it I substituted the tomatoes for a few cans of rotel (hot because we love spice). I also add freshly sliced jalapeno when cooking garlic an onion. Since the corn only didn't seem filling enough I also add sliced carrots and green beans to make it more of a chicken stew and to make it more filling.
I add half the sour cream when cooking, and reserve the other half to top the soup when serving. The other day when I made this I added some cubed cream cheese to give it a thicker and creamier texture. I also add a few dashes of cayenne, again because we like the spice.
This is a good soup that can be adjusted to any taste. Simple and easy and it does make a lot which is great for freezing or leftovers.

text:
one of the best flavored soups I've ever tasted. This recipe is a MUST TRY!   I make soups all the time, I'm so thrilled to find this recipe.  I will be adding it to my list of favorite family dinners! The soup looks as good as it tastes. Amazing.  I used a whole chicken- which made the flavor incredible. I used two cans of black beans and one can of pinto beans. I also substituted one large diced carrot for corn which we loved. Everything else I followed to a T. My family LOVED this spicy yummy comfort meal.  It's a delicious leftover too! Lastly, it took longer for me to prepare than it said .... but worthy of the extra time!

text:
I have made this soup numerous times and vary the type of beans that I use.  Whatever I have in the pantry is put in.  I always add black beans, chili beans and either romano or chick peas to the mix.  Always thoroughly rinse the beans.  Usually turkey stock and some canned chicken stock for more flavor.  I only use 1 can of diced tomatoes and eliminate the whole tomatoes.  Add some red chili flakes for more spice and left over turkey.  I make a huge pot and freeze in containers for work.  An easy and nutritious lunch.  Great recipe!

text:
I made this recipe for a coworker whose husband was in the hospital. She loved it so I made it for my family and it was delicious. I made a few changes: I used 4 skinless/boneless chicken breasts cube, 1 tsp. mined garlic and 1 tsp. garlic powder, 4 tsps. chicken boullion and 1 (14oz.) can chicken broth, one can (14.5 oz.) peeled and diced tomatoes with green chilis, only 2 Tbsps. chili powder, deleted the whole peeled tomatoes, tomato soup and sour cream, used 1 (16 oz.) can chili beans undrained, added 1 (16 oz.) can black beans. I will definitely make this recipe again this winter.

Another yummy soup recipe from AR, which I love all the more because I always have the ingredients on hand! userID:
2258022
Display Name:
Sopranosong67
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/248988.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
From what a lot of other reviews have said, this recipe sounds like it would turn out delicious "as is" without any "tweaking."  However, I did the following and was extremely happy with the results.  I realized it didn't call for any cumin (which in my opinion is a must have when it comes to this kind of dish) so I used half chili powder (1 1/2 TBS) and half cumin (1 1/2 TBS.)  Instead of regular salt I used garlic salt seasoning that was mixed with parsley.  I added a large dash of Goya Adobo seasoning (another "must have" ingredient for anything mexican/spanish.)  I used 1 (15 oz) can undrained can of mild jalapeño black beans with lime juice (EXCELLENT FLAVOR!) in place of the chili beans, 2 undrained (15 oz.) cans of mexican seasoned stewed tomatoes in place of the 2 different types of tomatoes called for, and used 1 (15 oz) tub of medium FRESH salsa.  I put all the other ingredients from the recipe into the crockpot (raw boneless chicken breasts, pepper, condensed tomato soup, chicken bouillon, onion and garlic powder) and cooked on high for about 2-3 hours, then on low for about another 4 hours.  I then simply shredded the cooked chicken and threw it back in along with a bag of frozen corn.  Added shredded mexican cheese, a dollop of sour cream and cubed avocado on top of each individual serving.  PHENOMENAL FLAVOR!!!

text:
One of the most delicious soups I've ever tasted. I made a few changes. I made a half recipe and that was enough for ten people-plus seconds. if you make the whole batch it would feed an army. 

So this is what i did:

I used chicken broth instead of water, and i did not add the salt that the recipe calls for because the broth adds enough flavor.

i used HOT chuncky salsa (is supposed to be spicy!). I didn't bother putting in the can of whole tomoatoes (it would be a bit hard to eat) so i did the one can of diced tomatoes, plus another can of diced tomatoes in substitute of the whole tomatoes. 

instead of only using half the can of corn, i used the whole thing-why not!

bring it to a boil for about 5 minutes then let simmer for 30. this soup is fantastic!!!

text:
Wow, these ingredients are all super healthy...you've got your protein and antioxidants...low calorie too if you don't add the sour cream.  I will try one reviewer's suggestion and go buy some non fat plain yogurt.  I think the only iffy thing about the ingredients is the canned stuff with the BPA controversy, but I know I'm being nit picky.  Ok, as for taste, it's like a 4.7 stars.  I was uncertain that the flavors will come out, but the longer that I cooked it for, the stronger it became.  I ended up adding the listed amount of salt.  The corn really adds a nice sweet touch to the dish.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4188320.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome soup Catherine!  I brought a big bowl into work for my lunch and as soon as it came out of the microwave I had a crowd of coworkers hovering around asking what smelled so good, gave everyone a taste and had to promise I'd make more to share next time!  I have a thing about canned foods, so I made mine with with dry pinto beans (soaked overnight), used 9 fresh roma tomatoes (boiled until the skin could be easily peeled off, then chopped), organic chicken broth instead of water, and just put it all in a crockpot (with the uncooked chicken) and let it cook on low all day (10 hours?) until the beans were tender.  At the end, I added some seasonings to taste (italian seasoning, basil, chopped fresh cilantro, and extra pepper).  Came out wonderful!  I can't wait to make another batch, think we'll freeze half and bring it with us on our next camping trip!  Enjoy!

text:
I've been making a version of this for years, adding strips of roasted chilies and pinto beans. I was a little skeptical of the tomato soup, but glad I tried it, as I liked the addition. I love recipes that hold up well to variations based on individual preferences. Used boneless, skinless thighs cooked and shredded in the crockpot and added all other ingredients directly in there and simmered until we were ready to eat. My husband, 3 year-old daughter, and I are all sick with colds, and we found this a perfectly delicious twist on the old standby chicken soup.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe and my kids do too even though they are extremely picky and don't like tomatoes. however I did make some changes because of previous cooking experiences. I also left out the whole tomatoes as others did but I added a an extra can of Hunt's basil, oregano and garlic flavored diced tomatoes, I can't help it I love those diced flavored tomatoes! Instead of chili beans, I used 2 cans of pinto beans and a can of black beans, my family loves beans so we added an extra can. I also prefer frozen corn so I used that instead of the can corn but I am sure it tastes just as good either way. I used two onions instead of one because our family does enjoy our veggies. Instead of using bouillon cubes, which can make some recipes to salty, I used the 98% fat free and low sodium chicken broth. If you find the recipe not salty enough, you can always add salt to your liking, but since I love using Tony Chachere's creole seasoning which has salt in it, I didn't need to add salt. Also, I do like the chili powder flavor when added but I don't measure it, I use my eye to call it and then do a taste test. You get the hang of it after so many years of eyeballing seasoning. I don't use as much chicken, usually 6 breast halves since you are shredding the chicken anyway and 6 breast halves is still a lot of chicken in this soup, but if you want A LOT of chicken then use 8. I also use fresh parsley because I prefer the taste of fresh herbs. I have tried this recipe with and w

Our family absolutely loves this soup! EVERYONE who has eaten this at our house has asked for the recipe! It also makes a HUGE amount of soup. We freeze what we don't eat, and it makes a great quick meal after soccer or softball practice!  Thanks for an awesome recipe Catherine.

text:
Sinfully tasty and rich. I cooked it all in one big pot to make it simpler. Cook chicken with olive oil, onion and garlic. Add herbs and seasonings, water and the rest EXCEPT for the beans and corn. Simmered soup for one hour and the chicken shredded like a champ. Threw in the beans and corn last. Super spicy, next time less chili powder for us and next time only 1 can of tomatoes will be fine. I agree about the sour cream. Add as desired to each serving. Yummy!

text:
WOW! This was great! The best part about it is that I had mostly everything in my cabinet. Lets make this easier tho. Throw everything in the pot! I do not think that the soup needs all that tomato stuff (but thats just me!) I used everything but substituted the cans of peeled tomatoes, whole tomatoes and tomatoe soup for just one jar of "CALDO DE TOMATE" by Knorr. I used about a handful. You can add as much flavor as you like. I also used Rotel tomatoes. For the Finishing touch, when I made my bowl I crushed fritos and added shredded cheese! OMG talk about good! I think all those cans of tomatoes would have been way to much for my taste. You can even add Creole and sauted (sp?) mushrooms!

Only used 3 chicken breasts, used half chicken broth and half water instead of 2 qts water, did not use whole tomatoes, did not add chili powder, and did not add beans. Kept everything else the same and was voted the best soup at our office soup/chowder/stew cook-off (people usually go for the chowder so this was an accomplishment). cooked and shredded the chicken first then cooked everything else together in a slow cooker over night on medium and kept on low the next morning until lunch time.

Very good! I will certainly make this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious! I made some minor changes for the sake of purer, fresher flavors. Instead of jarred salsa, I added the ingredients of salsa - extra tomatoes and onion, diced jalapeno and chopped cilantro. And instead of condensed tomato soup (which contains high-fructose corn syrup) I used a small can of tomato paste. And instead of chili powder I used chipotle powder, and frozen corn instead of canned. Topped with shredded cheddar/pepper jack and broke tortilla chips into it - fantastic! This recipe makes a LOT of soup. I made it in my 5-quart dutch oven, but then had to pull out another pot and transer some because it wouldn't all fit in the 5-quart. Now I just hope it freezes well.

text:
Absolutely wonderful soup!  Complex flavors, yet so ridiculously easy to make.  How can it be so good?!?! 

Like others, I reduced the chili pepper substantially.  I am a baby when it comes to spicy heat, so I reduced from 3T to 1T, and that was the perfect temp for me.  I think that few people would truly enjoy the intense heat of 3T.  

I serve with a chunky lime wedge, as I fnid that fresh lime or lemon juice squeezed just before eating brightens the flavors. 

I've made this vegetarian and it's great that way.  Enjoy!!

text:
I made this pretty much as the recipe states, only I have to puree all the tomatoes because of one family members dislike of chunky tomatoes. I also pureed the salsa for the same reason.(I started pureeing the tomatoes because of this one person but now I've found I like the texture it gives to the soups, chilis, and stews, etc. less watery and more creamy.) I also added about a half tsp of celery salt and 1 tsp. Mexican Oregano. I't's simmering now and tastes fantastic already even without adding the chicken back in or the sour cream. May just serve the SC on the side this time to see if it add or detracts from the flavors in the soup. Thanks for the recipe.

Display Name:
Joy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is delicious!  I've made it numerous times and everyone I've shared it with loves it too.  After reading other reviews I too made some changes.  I leave out the can of whole peeled tomatoes, replace 1/2 a can of tomato soup with 1/2 can of enchilada sauce, use frozen corn, and add an extra tablespoon of chili powder (and sometimes a little cayenne, I like things spicy).  The first time I made it I simmered the chicken for the listed time and it was way too long, my chicken turned out dry and it left very little broth.  Just keep an eye on it and pull it off when the chicken is no longer pink.  I also accidentally used cream cheese instead of sour cream and it was quite good, made it a little more creamy and thick.  Using different varieties of salsa also changes things up a bit, my favorite I've used was a chipotle one.  Regardless of the these little changes the soup is great!!

text:
My family is HOOKED!!! The soup is excellent as is but i made a few changes. I boil chicken in about 4 cups of water then remove chicken and shred. I put the cubes in the water then add the chicken back in. I got a containter of Pico De Gallo at my grocery store in the produce section and used that. SO MUCH BETTER THAN SALSA!!  I use three cans of corn because i like corn. I will use any sort of tomatoe i have around whether canned or from the garden. I eyeball all of the spices. I used garlic, hot chili powder, and salt and pepper. The Pico de Gallo has jalepenos and cilantro in it for more kick too. I like this soup so much because you can use whatever you like or whatever you have in the pantry and it will always turn out great. My kids can never wait on it to simmer for hours so they eat it as soon as it's warm. I let it just sit on the stove for awhile then later i'll take it off to cool and keep some in fridge and freezer. Freezes well. This wil always be a staple in our menu. So far i have given the recipe to more than a dozen people.

text:
This was very good.  We were somewhere in between just liking it and loving it.  It wasn't spicy to us at all!  I was hesitant about using tomato soup in this, but I actually found this recipe to try and use up some tomato soup, and it was surprisingly good in this soup -- those who are hesitant don't be afraid to try it!  I halved the recipe but went ahead and used the whole can of soup.  I also used some chicken I'd already cooked and shredded, so I skipped the whole chicken/broth stage and just threw everything in the crockpot.  I skipped the corn (hubby doesn't like corn in soup... don't ask me why!), but I added some lentils to thicken/bulk out the soup.  We each stirred our own sour cream and some cheese into it at the end.  All in all, a very good taco soup.  I think on it's own it would be a 3-4 star soup, but with the crushed tortilla chips, some cheese, and sour cream it really is tasty!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is 5 stars exactly as written.  I did use 5 cups of chicken stock instead of water/bullion to bring down the sodium.  I also prefer shredding the chicken as stated in the recipe because it fits the other textures in the soup.  Not sure about the suggestion of leaving out the Chili beans, Whole Tomatoes and sour cream for calorie/fat savings.   Typically, Chili beans have about 10 more calories (no fat difference) per 1/2 cup than black or other beans and the flavor the chili beans adds is worth it.  For calorie savings use Reduced Fat (360 calories for 8oz divided by 8 huge servings) or Fat Free (if you must - calories are usually the same as Reduced, only fat grams drop from 3.5 to 0) sour cream and the whole tomatoes are nothing but nutritious.   The real calorie/fat saver without diminishing taste/flavor, texture and style of this soup would be to omit the 3 Tbsp of olive oil (between 300-360 calories) and use 3 sprays (0 calories) olive oil spray.  I've always been a fan of dropping the calories/fat where it has the least impact on the taste.

text:
I had half of a large batch of chicken fajita filling that I made the night before that I added to this soup, eliminating the cooking chicken in water step. I did add a little more spice, like cumin, oregano, paprika, and coriander only because I thought the soup could use something other than just heat. Adding the tomato soup added a little sweetness, something I would have never come up with on my own. Next time, I'll take some of the other reviewer's advice and saute the chicken and vegetables in EVOO before adding the rest of the ingredients. It'll add more flavor. I think I'd leave out the chicken bouillion, as it made it a little salty. Otherwise, great idea for a soup. Serving it with just a bit of shredded monterey jack and sour cream made it really shine. NOTE: This is also good with pork.

userID:
2904173
Display Name:
Jackie B.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/74434.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good. If you want to make it better, healthier and quicker, here's what you do:
1.Make it a one-pot-dish and buy an already made chicken, preferably a rotisserie. Sautee the ingredients that need to be sauteed first, add other ingredients, and add the chicken and spices last.
2. Omit the whole tomatoes. They just don't make sense.
3. If you like it spicy, which this dish is NOT really originally add chayenne pepper to taste. 1 tsp should be perfect.
4. Add cumin seed ground- 1 tablespoon for some extra flavor.
5. Substitute the sour cream for some fat free sour cream, or to make it really healthy plain fat free yogurt- but you risk changing the taste with yogurt. Go for the fat free sour cream if you don't want to chance it-and add it LAST. Reserve some for the top along with shredded cheese.
6.Don't let it taste like enchilada filling-thats just not a good taste for a soup to have. CHUNK the chicken, don't shred it.
8. Add black beans instead of chili beans-they are so much healthier- and rinse thouroughly. Everyone knows the starches on the beans just don't taste good. To make it more of a 'chili' add kidney, black AND white beans. 3 cans won't be too much especially if you spiced it up with chayenne pepper.
9. To spice it up even more get the diced tomatoes WITH jalapenos or green peppers. Jalapenos are good for the metabolism but bad for the weak-stomached or heartburn prone.
10. Go with the crusty bread- or even better, put it in a sourdough bread boule.
11. ENJ

This makes a ton but I am glad as I get to freeze and enjoy this soup many times over. Gotta go, my mouth is watering and I'll think I'll reach for one of my frozen containers of this soup!

OH MY GOSH!!!!  AMAZING!!!  All 6 (4 kids) of us ate it up like crazy!  I changed almost NOTHING - Lightly sauteed onion & garlic, then browned meat slightly ( I like the flavor better) then added the broth & stuff from first paragraph.  AFter an hour, I removed chicken, shredded it and added the rest of the stuff ( except sour cream, let everyone put a dollop on their soup).  I added a dash of smoked paprika also, as that is a fav in our house.
 DH LOVED this and said it was hearty (soup isn't normally enough for him, so I make him a little something extra - he didn't even touch it tonight!!!)  Thanks AUNTTAF!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This makes a  LOT of soup so there's plenty for leftovers.  This soup is wonderful; it's easy and uses general pantry ingredients that can also be easily substituted for others one may have on hand.

To speed things up a bit I used a whole store-bought rotisserie chicken that I chopped up in the processor.  I skipped the can of whole tomatos but added: 

1 large can of chopped green chilies (Sam's Choice)
1 teaspoon cumin
2 tablspoons fresh parsley
1 tablespoon dried cilantro

I also used boxed, no sodium added chicken broth instead of boullion cubes/water, black beans instead of chili beans, frozen corn instead of canned, and reduced fat sour cream.

This recipe's a keeper.  DH LOVED it!

Unlike the review below, I think it is well worth the 5 star rating.  I did everything except for adding salt.  I mean extra salt with 5 cubes of bouillon?? No need for that if you ask me. My wife's devil horns were starting to surface after an hour and a half when I originally said, "Yeah baby, just 45 minutes and we'll be eating". text:
This is definitely a 5 star soup-even though I did make some changes. I cut the beans portion in half, as we don't care for them too much. Next time I think I may use the same amount of beans, but black beans. Anywho, I added 1 tablespoon of Siracha hot sauce plus 2 tablespoons of chili powder instead of just the three tablespoons of chili powder. I also omitted the sour cream altogether. I do also think next time I will add another can of corn to take place of the one lacking can of beans. It is a great soup, and only gets better the next few days in the fridge! Thanks so much for the recipe!!!

None
text:
Delicious, healthy, and easy! I halved the recipe using the calculator, followed the recipe with these slight changes: substituted 1 qt chicken stock for the water and bouillon cubes, used 1 whole medium onion, 1 bag frozen southwest corn for the canned corn. For the tomatoes, I used 1 can of fire roasted tomatoes, 1 can ro-tel, and the entire can of tomato soup. Like other reviewers, I serve the sour cream on the side. Halved, this recipe makes at least 10 servings, which is great because the leftovers are even better the next day. Ran this through the WW recipe builder and for 12 servings this recipe is 3 points. Thank you so much for posting this recipe!

text:
Absolutely delicious!  Definitely one of the best soups I've made.  I made a few revisions because I didn't have all of the ingredients - I didn't have tomato soup, so used a can of tomato paste instead, frozen corn instead of canned, an extra can of diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes, and used chicken broth instead of chicken bouillon.  I didn't use sour cream and used black beans instead of the chili beans.  I let it simmer for a couple of hours and it was absolutely fabulous!

text:
EXCELLENT! I make a few modifications, I use less chicken (there is PLENTY of meat with 4-6 breasts) and I add several chopped carrots when I sautee the onion. I throw in a bit of crushed red pepper flakes and use fresh salsa rather than jar salsa. I use 2 cans of diced tomatoes and no whole tomatoes. I also leave out the chili beans and the sour cream. People can top it if desired. I make this in HUGE batched to freeze extars and it has been a hit with everyone who tries it.

userID:
1951306
Display Name:
jd
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
20
favoritesCount:
408
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this soup definitely beats the canned chicken tortilla soup that i usually buy. the portions are very hefty and it will fill u up. i cut the recipe in half and i made the following changes based on user reviews and because i forgot some things at the store: only used 2 chicken breasts and thought it was more than enough meat, omitted the salt, instead of the jar of salsa i used a container of diced tomatoes, green peppers, and onions from the grocery store, omitted the cans of tomatoes and instead doubled the amount of tomato soup (might add some fresh tomatoes next time too), used frozen corn, canned chili beans in medium sauce, and low fat sour cream- couldn't taste the difference, but i wouldn't recommend omitting the sour cream altogether. served with shredded cheese and corn tortilla chips. this was the first time i've ever made soup and i was pretty impressed with how it came out-perfect amount of flavor and spice. my only complaint is that it tasted too salty to me-especially with the tortilla chips-even though i used reduced sodium tomato soup. i think next time i will use reduced sodium bouillon cubes and/or make fresh beans.

text:
I took this to a soup putlock and it was all gone and sadly the others were not.  Everyone asked for the recipe and I could not lie so I told them where to find it.  I will be making this again when the weather cools off!Update: I just tried this in the slow cooker and it was so easy.  I used chicken stock and all the spices, tomatoes, salsa and tomato soup, and put in 2 frozen chicken breast for a half recipe.  I turned it on low for 6 hours.  When it was done I shredded the chicken and put it back in, added the beans and corn and let it heat through.  So great and so easy and so much food.  I leave out the sour cream becasue of allergies, but I'm sure it would be good with it too.  Try it in the slow cooker, it is so much easier.

I'm not a soup lover, but this was AWESOME! Just a couple of changes: I used a 12 oz bag of frozen corn, and just one 28 oz can of crushed San Marzano tomatoes (they're the best!). Served it topped with Mexican blend cheese, blue corn chips, sour cream, and chopped avocado.

userID:

Display Name:
pdizzy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/337863.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The beauty of this soup is that because of its versatility, if you have a decent pantry, you will have a variation of most of the ingredients on hand.  I read a lot of the reviews, and being from Arizona, wanted to add some serious heat.  If you like heat, I would suggest these modifications.  Broth -- didn't change a thing.  I saved the leftovers and could just drink the broth, cooked the chicken perfectly.  Used frozen chicken tenderloins.  Used 2 small cans of runny Mexican salsa and a can of chipotle peppers in adobo sauce.  Omitted the can of whole tomatoes.  For tomates -- used one can of diced tomatoes with garlic and onion, and two cans of Rotel.  Added dash of cayenne.  For beans, used one can chili and one can black beans.  Served with these help yourself add ons:  heated up tortilla chips, sliced black olives, shredded cheese, and dollop of sour cream.  Much better than most chicken tortilla soups and a heck of a lot spicer.  Would open up your sinuses if you had a cold.  Kudos to Catherine!

My pan ended up being smaller than I thought (oops) so I added one can of diced tomatoes, one can of beans (drained- I only eat them that way), the can of tomato soup and the jar of salsa.  I then poured on about three cups of the broth.  I let it simmer for an hour, meaniwhile deciding it needed some paprika and cumin and WOW!!  I mixed in a dollop of sour cream at the end along with a bit of shredded cheese and served with cornbread.  This is a keeper- it's delicious and makes enough for my boyfriend and I to eat for a few days!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is fabulous! I made a couple changes as well...I didn't simmer the chicken for an hour...only until cooked through, about 15 minutes. I then strained the broth through cheese cloth. I only used about 6 breasts, I added a can of black beans, used chili hot breans, 2 cups fresh medinm heat salsa, no whole tomatoes and no canned soup. I did use 3 T of chili powder and instead of stirring in sour cream, I had some fat free half and half, so I stirred in about 1/2-3/4 cup. I added in more than 5 cups of the broth also.....might as well make a huge pot, right? I used a 16 oz bag of frozen corn, not canned....I had cilantro on hand so I added a good handful of that too. After it was all put together and up to heat, I stuck the pot into a 185 degree oven for the afternoon...served it with shredded mexican blend cheese and sour cream for granish and corn bread....it was out of this world!!
I think it will feed 10-12 people easy.

text:
So good!  I forgot to add the sour cream, and it was great without it!  Will add some to individual bowls to try it.  I only used 3 large breasts, but think I will up it to 4 next time and that should be plenty.  I made some changes to make it a little healthier and to only use one pot. Boiled the chicken for an hour with only two bullion cubes, it created a nice stock.  Removed chicken to cool, and added remaining ingredients (minus the oil) to stock.  Subbed a can of diced tomatoes with chilies for the can of whole tomatoes.  Left out the tomato soup, added an extra can of corn, and subbed black beans for chili beans.  Also added some red pepper to taste, I like spicy.  Simmered that for a half hour while the chicken cooled and I shredded it, added the chicken back and I had a great big pot of delicious, healthy soup.  Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
what's really great about this recipe is that it uses things you probably already have in your pantry. i was looking for a crock pot soup when i found this recipe.  i did cook the chicken in the crock(on low for several hours)but ended up finishing on the stove...it was too much for the crockpot.  i used my 8qt stock pot and it wasn't too big.  my chicken was so tender from the crock that it melted in the mouth AND in the pot...next time i will not shred but cube it instead.  i'm bad about tweaking a recipe and i had planned on dropping a dollop of the sour cream on top of the soup for "presentation".  i followed the directions instead and was glad.   the sour cream really rounds out the flavor.  i also added a little cubed avocado to each bowl...maybe a tablespoon or so.  this makes 8 hearty portions.  serve with your favorite cornbread.

text:
As per the recipe by LASVEGAS00, I made mine in the crock pot. I halved the recipe and made the following adjustments: "Minus olive oil, corn and beans, threw everything in my crockpot (chicken breasts whole) and set on low for 8 hours. Last 2 hours, I removed chicken breasts to shred (didn't take much as they fell apart from being in the juices), added chicken meat back in, 1 can of black beans (rinsed and drained), and the corn." However, I did forget to add the corn, black beans, and chilli powder until I had eaten one bowl of this deliciousness. It was great without it too. After I added them in, I decided I actually preferred the flavor without the chili powder. Next time I will leave it out altogether.

city:

country:

text:
My family loves this recipe; however, I have changed a few things over the past year of using it. 
I'm a big Trader Joes shopper so I modified it so I don't have to go to a 'regular' store...all ingredients are from TJs... I boil 4 breasts and shred, add to that broth an additional 2 boxes of chicken broth, a tub of precut veggie mix (celery, carrots, onions), 1 can of black beans drained ( omit chili beans) , 2 large  cans of diced tomatoes drained ( in place of whole tomatos and t -sauce, 1 bag of frozen sweet corn. I use all of the suggested seasoning and sour cream. Absolutely delicious ! For gatherings of folks who love it super-duper spicy - and to the recipe's seasoning list 1 packet of Trader Joes Taco Seasoning! I serve this with a side of TJ's cornbread (box mix)! All delicious and healthy, too!

text:
Wow, fantastic!! Of course like lots of others I customized it to fit what our family likes. We don't like tomato or onion chunks so I substituted granulated onion for chopped onion. So I then I pressed the garlic into the simmering chicken and strained the broth before adding it to the other pot. I also omitted all 3 cans of tomatoes but added extra tomato soup and pureed salsa (since I can them in fall) to compensate for the weight given of how much tomatoes I omitted. Superb flavor! Thanks so much, we did enjoy!!

text:
So tasty!!! I made this for myself, my mother and sister for dinner tonight. Both my mother and sister left nothing more than a drop in their bowls. The soup turned out being a little more spicier than I had anticipated or aimed for, but that was entirely my goof... I accidentally added 3 tbsp of cayenne pepper mistaking it for chili powder! I'm such a klutz. Oh well. I went ahead and added a bit of chili powder anyway, figuring what the heck after I realized my mistake. I was a little worried, but the soup turned out delicious! Maybe it had a little bit more of a kick than it needed, but still, delicious. I'll definitely make this again. Though, I think I'll replace the can of whole tomatoes with another can of diced tomatoes. I just found the whole tomatoes to be in the way and wished I had more tomatoes to spoon up in each bite. And I'll be sure to leave the cayenne pepper out next time and double check the label for chili powder. Hah! Also, I should mention that I followed the advice of others and left the shredded cheese and sour cream until the end to use as a sort of topping. I can't wait to make this again! So tasty.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!! I was worried it may be too spicy so only did 1.5 tablespoons of chili powder. Also, husband doesn't like too many chunks of tomatoes or onions (lame!) so I did only one can of tomatoes, two cans of tomato soup and used Lipton's onion dry soup mix (and dry onion flakes because I didn't have onion powder)... still gave the flavor without my husband having to bite into a chunk of onion. Also put 2 cans of black beans instead of the chili to make it healthier. Topped with avocado made this yummy soup even better!! 
I followed someone else's advice to make the cooking easier: Cut chicken into bite size pieces, boiled in (I did a little over 2 qts of water because I actually cooked 6 full chicken breasts) water for 20 minutes then added all the rest of the ingredients and simmered for an hour. Made a lot, nice to put in baggies and freeze to pull out for later!

I love love love this soup. I don't use 8 breasts (I did the first time). I also leave out the corn--just a personal preference. I only use the diced tomatoes. Otherwise, I follow the recipe. It freezes GREAT. I put single servings in a ziplock and put those in a large freezer bag. Tip: use the paddle attachment on your stand mixer to shred the chicken....works like a charm!  Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

ebeth

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a flavorful, tasty soup! My husband mentioned how much he liked it about 3 times :) I made a few changes to suit our tastes: I omitted the salt (the bouillon cubes have quite a bit as it is) and the sour cream, just because I didn't feel like they were necessary. I also omitted the onion, just because we're not huge fans of onions. I substituted one can of diced tomatoes for a can of Rotel to give it a kick (and boy it did!) and instead of whole tomatoes I used crushed (I just prefer the texture). I used frozen corn rather than canned (I think it tastes more fresh) and substituted a can of drained, rinsed black beans for one of the cans of chili beans. I made the soup the day before we ate it, so that the flavors could combine and it would be even more delicious. It ended up being quite spicy, but we loved it!

Also, just a tip: if you have a Kitchen Aid mixture, use the paddle attachment to shred chicken perfectly! I just added the (hot) chicken breasts to the mixing bowl (no liquid needed) and used the mixer for about 20-30 seconds. Couldn't be easier :)

Display Name:
Gloria

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/401597.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good flavor but we did not just love it..  This soup has what I call a "southwestern" flair which I normally love.  For Crock Pot convenience, I tweaked the recipe just a bit.  I shredded a whole rotisserie chicken and added only 4 cups of (purchased) chicken broth.   I did not add the bouillon cubes because I thought the canned broth would be stronger than broth from chicken breasts as recommended.   However, I think next time, I will keep it in there.  Though I did saute the onions and garlic as directed, I really think it would taste the same if I had just thrown that in the pot with the rest of the ingredients, minus the oil, of course. For the sour cream, I used fat-free but I'm not sure what any sour cream does for it.  Finally, because I think most soups taste even better the next day, I put the crock pot full of soup in the refrigerator overnight and the next day, cooked it on low for 10 hours so it would be ready when we got home from work. I can't say I loved this soup but I think it is worth making again and  tweaking just a bit more to suit our tastes. BTW, this makes a lot of soup!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! This is SO good.  I only used 4 chicken breasts because the kind you can get at Costco are normally really large.  It made the perfect amount.  I didn't use onion powder because I didn't have any.  I also only had about 8 oz of salsa, so I just used what I had.  Instead of a condensed can of tomato soup I used the organic Pacific brand of Roasted Red Pepper Tomato Soup (I filled one of the empty cans of tomatoes with the soup and it was the perfect amount). It was PERFECT!  I did add some salt at the end because I felt it needed just a tad more.  I didn't use chili beans because I didn't have any.  Instead I used kidney beans but think that black beans would work really well too.  The sour cream at the end is genius.  I normally just add it on top of other soups that I've made that are similar, but I love that it's added in.  The whole tomatoes are great!  Don't leave those out, like others have suggested.  It gives the soup more bulk!  They only thing I think I may add next time is some fresh chopped cilantro.  Great soup!  I will definitely be making again!

text:
I been looking for a good tortilla soup and I came across this one and this was the EXACT SOUP MY TASTE BUDS WANTED!  I love this soup!  I have made it over 5 times since I found the recipe 3 months ago.  I did skip the sour cream in the soup, I add it to my personal bowl if I feel like it, but it is superb without it.  I don't add the can of whole tomatoes, I just add another can of diced tomatoes, I really love tomatoes so the more the merrier.  I also only use two chicken breasts because that is enough chicken for me.  I also usually use all the water from the boiled chickens not just 5 cups.  One more thing I add is one to two small cans of green chilies, I have had the soup with them and without them and it is good both ways, I just like green chilies.  I freeze a bunch of it and it's the same goodness from when u first make it!

There are so many ingredients I almost changed my mind about making this one...glad I didn't!  It's fantastic.  I thought a jar of salsa was wierd, but it all comes together in the end. I don't typically comment on recipes, though I get quite a few from this site on a regular basis.  This is an incredibly easy and wicked good recipe!  My rendition was probably a little higher fat because I used what I had on hand, however, I can imagine it would taste just as good with the low fat options.  The things I changed a bit:  I used a whole cut up chicken instead of breasts (I think the bones help add flavor to the stock), skipped the whole peeled tomatoes and substitued a can of Rotel instead, and I used frozen corn in place of canned (I am not a fan of squishy corn).  Otherwise I stuck to the recipe - EXCELLENT JOB AUNTTAF - it was a HOME RUN with the family!  This one is a keeper and going into the weekly rotation! :)

I made this the other night with leftover Thanksgiving turkey.  It was delicious!  I made it on Saturday, then put it in my slow cooker on Sunday for a few hours.  We had about 10 adults over after church and there was even some leftover.  I omitted the whole peeled tomatoes and instead of fresh garlic I used the minced kind in the fridge.  I put the shredded cheese and sour cream on the side.  You can't go wrong with this recipe!  Oh, and it's not too spicy especially for someone as sensitive as me.  I plan to make some more and freeze it in small batches to eat over the next couple of months.  Definitely a keeper.

I've made this recipe COUNTLESS times, all with great success!  Variation can come from the type of beans to the type of salsa used.  I recommend medium southwest type salsa & getting a mixed blend of beans.  I always let the recipe warm in the crock pot over night to let the spices settle into the chicken - always a hit with the family!

***UPDATED - this soup is a staple in our house now.  If I don't make it at least once a month and have a bowl or two frozen for a quick lunch, my husband will ask, "Isn't it time to make some Catherine's?"

text:
Excellent! I made it exactly by the recipe, and the soup turned out phenomenal! I am actually proud of myself for how well it came out!

I recommend cooking the chicken in the water to make the broth and adding the sour cream to the soup while cooking. These things really add to the rich quality. The sour cream will not be overbearing. Instead it will add just the right color and favor to the soup (believe me--I am not a fan of sour cream). I shredded the chicken with the help of a vegetable peeler, and the process took only a minute or two.

text:
After reviewing other inputs, I made the following changes to make this even easier and time saving.  I began by cooking the onion and garlic in olive oil until slightly browned.  I then added all the mentioned seasonings, 16 oz. jar med. chunky salsa, 2 cups frozen corn, 14.5 can petite diced tomatoes, 28 oz. can crushed tomatoes, 1 can chili beans, 1 can black beans, 5 cups chicken stock and 2 13 oz. cans chicken breast meat which I shredded.  I simmered for 30 minutes and served with roasted garlic bread.  We thoroughly enjoyed this meal!  It's a keeper!

text:
The only thing I changed about this recipe was to cook it in the crockpot.  I didn't even consider that the liquid in the recipe would not evaporate from a crockpot like it would on the stove top, so my soup ended up too watery.  If I make it again I will either do it on the stove top as the recipe calls for or, if I make it in the crockpot again, I will reduce the water.  I have a 7-quart crockpot, which I think is the largest size available, and all the ingredients did not fit.  I ended up leaving out part of the chicken, but there was still more than enough chicken. I used medium-hot salsa, but I think I would go with hot if I make it again. In my opinion, the best thing about this recipe is it makes enough to feed my husband and me and to give some away and/or freeze some.

A delicious change from "regular" chicken soup.  I've already made this twice and shared recipe with family who also gave it 5 stars. text:
I thought this was just OK.  I'm kind of stumped at all of the 5-star ratings.  I followed the recipe exactly as written, but used fresh chopped tomatoes and corn instead of canned.  It was kind of bland and did not have *nearly* enough salt, even for my husband who doesn't like a lot.  This could partially be my fault, because I didn't account for the fact that canned vegetables probably have more sodium and needed less salt in the original recipe.  So if you use fresh veggies, you may need to add salt.  It was definitely spicy, but just enough.  If I make this again, I will use chicken breast w/ bone to make a more flavorful stock as well as some cumin in the soup.  Mexican shredded cheese and tortilla chips go well with this.

Update: Awesome when recipe is followed exactly (canned veggies instead of fresh).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum!  This soup is awesome!  I used 1 can chicken broth & the rest water w/bouillon cubes then added the spices & frozen chicken tenders. I brought to a boil and cooked until chicken was cooked (about 30 minute). Then I removed chicken and cut it up. I emptied the pan then added back in 5 cups of the broth, chicken and all the rest of the ingredients. Also I didn't have canned tomato soup so I just used crushed tomatoes and tomato paste. I also added some canned green chiles. I had everything on hand to make this and it was ready in about an hour. I added shredded cheese & crumbled tortilla chips on top. I love it, my husband thinks it's ok.  I will definitely make again!

None
text:
Wow!  What a soup!  It came out a little too spicy for my taste -- but this is fixable.  Use mild salsa, no chili powder, and chili beans that are not hot.  I think the first 8 ingredients simmered together looked (and smelled) fantastic.  I plan to do step one, add egg noodles, and enjoy it as a soup without the rest of the stuff!   Enjoy!
2nd review: Still love this recipe! I use the sour cream only as a topping because I prefer the soup to be more like chili and less like a cream-based soup. I use the full two quarts of broth (not just five cups) - and find it is hearty and flavorful.

text:
I scaled the recipe in half, simmered the carcass of a rotisserie chicken for the meat & broth, sauteed garlic, onion & celery  before adding 14.5 oz can tomatoes w/ gr chilies and 15 oz can black beans, cup salsa and box froz mixed veg (bec didn't have just corn), 5 cups of broth, 1 T chili powder, 1 t chipotle chili powder, 1/4 t ground red pepper.  I thought it was a bit watery so I took the cover off and simmered for an extra 20 mins until a bit thicker.  Delicious!

text:
I used frozen bulk chicken breasts,there were 7 breasts to the package 3 pounds.I put the frozen chicken into the soup pot with water and other ingredients called for, plus I added 1/4 tsp hot red pepper flakes. After bring it to a boil I let it simmer for 2 1/2 hours till chicken was tender..I followed most of the recipe except I omitted the 14.5 oz whole tomatoes. And added 1-15oz can drained black beans and another 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes to the  soup..When I served up the soup I crushed tortilla chips on top with shredded cheddar cheese..This is difinitely a winter time soup..We loved it..I was afraid it called for too much chicken but it turned out fine..Highly recommend this recipe if you like mexican spice...Thank U for a great soup recipe..

text:
This soup was fantastic!  First of all, I halved the recipe.  Then, instead of using chicken parts, I just used boneless, skinless chicken breasts, fried them up in a pan with some parsley, garlic, cayenne pepper, salt and pepper, and chopped them.  That way, I eliminated the wait!  For the chicken stock, I just used some Knorr's chicken stock powder and water (to make 5 cups).  For the chili-style beans, I added a can of chili-style pinto and kidney beans, which tasted great!  I also added a can of green chilies, and a diced tomato, but I eliminated the can of whole tomatoes.  My boyfriend raved that it tasted like taco soup!  We will make this recipe often!  Thank you, thank you, thank you!!

text:
Delicious! I left out the whole tomatoes (there was already enough tomato for my taste, and I love tomatoes). I also omitted the chili powder, as my children don't like too spicy. (Turns out they didn't like it anyway, so I'm going to use the chili powder next time.) I used about 6 pieces of leftover chicken, using the bones to make the broth and shredding the chicken in the food processor. I also used about 3/4 of a jar of hot salsa, and put sour cream on top of each bowl instead of in the soup. This recipe reminds me of a much more delicious taco soup. Hubby and I both loved it, and I like the versatility. I'm an experiment cooker, so it was nice to be able to add and remove ingredients based on my family's tastes.

text:
Too much meat, prep and cook time info is wrong and WAY TOO MUCH sodium. We modified by cutting down to 2 bouillon, used 4 not 8 chicken breast halves, frozen corn, and NO added salt. It was good but still more sodium than needed and plenty of chicken (maybe still too much).

Whole tomatoes with diced is unnecessary, stay with all diced. On the fence about the salsa plus canned tomatoes (next time I think we'll just use salsa, some low sodium Mexican seasoned tomatoes or fresh tomato salsa/pico de Gallo as others have mentioned).

For certain next time no bouillon cubes. Canned beans rather than canned chilli beans will cut the sodium down tremendously.

I have made this soup several times with no variations however tonight since my boyfriend and I are both sick it I made it again this time don't have any chilli beans in the house. I used dried rosemary, and few other spices added to the soup. I have read most of the complaints when it comes to being too salty add a little vinegar this will take away some of the salt. My boyfriend loves this soup its so simple to make I just throw everything in a crock-pot or on the stove top in a big pot to simmer for about 2 to 4 hour's. Even my boyfriend made this last month he was impressed by the simple recipe and he says he can't cook. We keep everything in stock for soups in the house. helpfulCount:
2
userID:
11472073
Display Name:
mearepaige
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
21
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was first drawn to this recipe because I had never used tomato soup (besides on its own) or salsa in a soup and I wanted to try it.  I made a couple changes though, to save time I cubed the raw chicken and cooked it in the olive oil on a pan with the onions and crushed garlic, then let the chicken cool before pulling with my hands.  Then I poured the medium chunky salsa and tomatoes (i used rotel tomatoes and chilies instead) in a pot with the tomato soup but only used 1 and a half cups of water, I figured I would add water as I went (didn't need anymore because of the liquid in the tomatoes).  I added 3 bay leaves, dried parsley, onion powder, garlic powder, chili powder (i didn't need any salt because chili powder is salty) and I put in a couple tablespoons of chicken Better Than Bullion instead of the cubes, much easier and tastier I think.  I decided I wanted it thick so I put in almost the whole container of SC and also added a half teaspoon of corn starch mixed with a tablespoon of water.  Then I put in about half a cup of raw rice.  It wasn't spicy so I added about 10 drops of green Tabasco and a drop or two of franks red hot (i would have used Sriracha but I was out), and some extra pepper. Also instead of chili beans I used one jar of kidney and one of black beans rinsed. I added cumin too for an extra kick and some adobo.  It came out awesome!  Basically a white chicken chili.

5

2013-09-24T15:45:55.15

Irony? I've only been cooking for the family for a year and this is the very first soup that I have made. At the risk of sounding immodest, this is the best soup that I have ever had. My wife didn't quite say the same but she did say that it was better than anything she has made herself.

PS: I followed the advice of "Chef 101" review:
Cook onions and garlic in thick bottomed pot, add dry spices and herbs, add uncooked chicken (small cuts) until no longer pink, then add canned ingredients. One can of diced tomatoes and one can of whole tomatoes. I did use canned corn though. 

This is going on the menu for one of our next dinner invites.

text:
Really delicious and easy!  I only used 4 large chicken breasts.  I cooked the onion and garlic in the olive oil.  Removed it and then browned the chicken a bit on both sides.  I then returned the onion & garlic to the pot and cooked the chicken in 4 cups chicken broth for an hour (rather than water and boullion.  I only used one can of tomatos - that was plenty.  Add all the other ingredients and cook for another 20-30 minutes.  Save the sour cream for the top.  I found the recommended amount of seasoning was perfect- spicey but not too hot.

text:
Been wanting to try this recipe for a long time and I finally served it for a dinner party last night.  This recipe turned out very well.  I used five chicken breasts and that was plenty.  Cooked them in chicken stock (32 oz) for one hour and removed from pan to cool and shred.  With the chicken stock left in the pan, I added a chopped onion and garlic.  I used 3 cans lo Rotel diced tomatoes, 1 teaspoon cumin, only 2 tablespoons of chili powder, a bag of frozen southwestern corn, 1 can black beans and one can of kidney beans.  I did use the jar of chunky salsa and tomato soup.  I served the sour cream on the side.  This was a wonderful dish and it received rave reviews.

text:
I've just made a batch of this soup and it's very, very tasty. The chicken is a bit overwhelmed by the amount of chilli bean and tomato but it's still a lovely meal. The next time I make this I will try substituting condensed chicken soup for the condensed tomato soup. This quantity made 8 English pints of soup so I have stashed loads in the freezer for eating and enjoying later. Thre recipe is very easy to make up and there could be endless variations on it which is what makes a good recipe great! I left out the 3tbsps of chilli powder as this might have been too hot for our tastes but otherwise I made no alterations. Thanks for sharing your recipe, Catherine :-) I only rate it 4* and not 5* because the chicken is overpowered by the chilli and tomato so I thought it was misleading to call it a chicken soup - more a chilli bean and tomato soup with chicken.

I modified based on the most popular reviews.  Made it in the crockpot, before leaving for work I put 4 split chicken breasts in along with the spices, a 32 oz container of chicken broth, a jar of salsa, a can of rotel, and a can of tomato soup.  When I got home I shredded the chicken and added some sauteed some onion and bell peppers, then frozen corn and a can of black beans and pinto beans.  This makes a lot, have lots in the freezer, but it's tasty and seems healthy, until you top with cheese, fritos and sour cream that is!

text:
AWESOME!  Made a real simple version using what I had and it was delicious. Boiled leftover whole rotisserie chicken 1hr in 6c water.  Removed skin and bones then added sauteed onion and garlic to chicken and broth.  Next, 2cans corn, 2cans dark red kidney beans and 1cup salsa.  1 can tomato puree and 1 can diced tomato.  2tbsp chili powder.  We couldn't stop eating it.

This is a really good soup. Very easy to adapt based on what you have on hand too. I used kidney beans instead of chili beans (I can't get those here), tomato sauce instead of condensed tomato soup and omitted the additional salt. Served with a little chedder cheese over top and it was delicious. Keep in mind, this makes a ton. I halved the recipe, used only two chicken breasts and still got 7 bowls. It also freezes very well.

city:

country:

text:
I loved this soup and my husband, who is not a soup lover, ate three servings! I followed the directions for the most part. I did cut the amount of chicken in half and substituted it for shrimp which I added at the end. It was the frozen precooked kind that just needed to be thrown in to defrost and heat up. When adding the chili powder I added a couple dashes of red pepper, but we like the extra heat. I also left out the can of whole peeled tomatoes and switched in black beans for the chili beans. I decided to double the corn amount and use Pico de Gallo instead of a can of salsa like another review suggested. Everything turned out great! The mixture of shrimp and chicken tastes great and looks delicious. I am thinking that the next time I make this soup I may add some rice, but haven't decided. I don't think it's necessary.

I didnt use chili beans or whole peeled tomatoes.  instead i used diced tomatoes w/green chiles.  i also used seasoned black beans.  not sure if that made a difference.  i used the sour cream as a garnish along with lots of cilantro, lime wedge and tortilla chips. the garnish really topped it off!  the only thing i would do different next time is not use the jar salsa but again use the tomatoes w/green chiles and  oh next time i will add some cheese on top - yum!
