text:
This recipe is easy and very delicious! I'm a student and so made it for myself and halved the recipe but it was A LOT and I ate it for 2 successive days. The changes I made, considering it a bit unhealthy, I substituted all kinds of canned tomatoes ingredient of same amount with fresh diced tomatoes together with its skin(anti-allergic properties+bioactive polyphenols+antioxidants, BUT careful washing is mandatory!); I substitued sour cream with yogurt, used dried basil instead of parsley, used 1 can of "Gallina Blanca tomato sauce for macaroni" in hand instead of condensed tomato soup, I substituted salsa with pickled cucumbers, and used only 1 cube of bouillon. I served with sweet dinner bun and it was the most wonderful meal. Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/268480.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great.  As other reviewers have said, the good thing about this recipe is its basic flexibility.  You can modify things and still keep the flavors you want.  I cut the recipe in half and instead of shredding the chicken, I cut two breasts into bite sized pieces.  I used fresh parsley instead of dry (I always prefer fresh herbs) and didn't add the salt (I took a queue from 'Uncle Ed's Nephew" about chili powder creating the sense of salt in a dish and held off until the soup was seasoned - in the end it didn't need the salt).  I also didn't add the salsa - instead I used diced tomatoes with chilis in them.  The flavors were really nice and hearty.

I used this recipe as a base for my own.  I made the broth in one pot with the chicken as the directions call for but then I also added 3 potatoes (cubed), 3 (chopped) celery stalks and 3 (chopped) carrots. I only made a couple of minor changes; I switched out one of the cans of chili beans with a can of black beans. I'm so glad I tried this recipe for my first soup!!

text:
Great soup!  I used canned chicken broth (1qt) with the one quart of water.  No bouillon.  I used the sour cream just as a topping (dollop on top of the bowl).  I cooked just 3 large bone-in chicken breasts in the crockpot in the broth/water mix with the garlic, onions and peppers.  I also left out the salt.  I think next time I will use all diced tomatoes; not sure why the whole tomatoes.  Anyway, the soup was a huge hit and made enough to feed a small army.  Thanks!

I halved the recipe and turned this into a slow cooker soup.

text:
I sauted onions and bell pepper in a little butter and olive oil.  When they began to soften, I poured in a bottle of Bud Light Lime, then added the rest of the ingredients according to the recipe until the broth.  Since I put the beer in, I only put in 4 cups of broth.  I simmered for about 30 minutes - seasoned with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and chili powder.  Then I topped with sour cream, shredded cheese, chives and blue corn tortilla chips.  Yum!

text:
This was excellent! I followed directions and simmered the chicken for an hour, rather than dice it up and mix in the ingredients right away, and it turned out exceptionally well. After an hour, I took the chicken out and it practically shredded itself under my knife it was so tender. The aroma was incredible. I left out the whole tomatoes (who wants exploding tomato juice in their face?) and used a tub of grocery store extra-hot salsa, which eliminated any need for more chili powder or cayenne. Only problem? The recipe sorely lacks green pepper. That will be a must next time. Also, Monterey Jack cheese goes beautifully on top.

text:
This soup is restaurant worthy!  Absolutely wonderful and great on a cold night.  I agree that the whole tomatoes make this soup a little tough to eat.  They're large and require cutting and they are really hot too.  I'll omit them next time and use one can chili beans, one can black beans rinsed and drained.  I will also slice avocado and put it on top of each individual serving.  The chicken only took about 20 minutes to cook through.  I'll probably use 2 1/2 quarts of water because I only had 4 cups of broth at the end and ended up using store bought stock for my 5th cup.  Green chili's might spice this up but honestly it doesn't need it.  Serve with tortilla chips or quesadillas... if that's how you spell it =)

text:
Unbelievably tasty and pretty healthy too!  I realized at the last second that I was out of chicken boullion, but it still turned out great without it.  I also did not add the sour cream, and next time I won't use the whole tomatoes - I don't see the point of them really. 

I made a huge batch and froze it in individual containers to bring to work, and it works out great!  I just take each portion out of the freezer a night or two before and stick it in the refrigerator...an easy and healthy workday lunch!  If I want to indulge a little, I throw some sour cream, cheddar cheese, and crushed fritos on top.  I'm so glad I found this recipe!  Thanks!!!

I have made this recipe twice now and it just gets better!  My husband loves it!  The first time I made it I used chicken as called for, but the second time I used left over Turducken from New Year's.  Both were delicious. text:
Very good and very easy! I made the following subs/changes: left out whole tomatoes per other reviewers' suggestions, used about 2/3 amount of chicken, used leftover chipotle-seasoned pintos instead of chili beans, and left out chili powder. Perhaps the chipotle remnants were enough, but it was plenty spicy without the chili powder. I also used "medium" heat salsa. It's a bit salty with all the canned products, so I'd recommend low-sodium canned goods and then salting to taste at the end. Definitely a keeper in our house!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING! 

I substituted fresh Cilantro for the Parsley and I think that it adds great flavor to this recipe. I recommend it. I also added 1/2 of a green pepper. Also a great addition.  

I also substituted boneless, skinless chicken breast STRIPS. I found them easier to cook and shred. 

I also recommend using a fresh salsa, the kind usually found in the deli section of the grocer in the plastic tubs, rather than the mass-produced salsa in the jar. The salsa will adjust the spice and flavor of this recipe, so if you want something spicier, get a spicier salsa. 

I have to say it was even better the second day after marinating overnight in the fridge. This takes a while to cook, but it is amazing!

text:
I turned this recipe into a crockpot recipe.  I omitted the water, and dumped everything but the corn and sour cream into a crockpot.  I used two large, bone in breasts.  Cooked in crockpot on high for 5 hours, removed the chicken, let it cook and shredded it, and added it back to the pot with the corn, and turned the pot on warm until ready to serve.  It was awesome on a cold rainy day!

text:
As usual I never scale back a recipe, so I followed measures shown - it was great for dinner, lunch and dinner..ha ha! In fact, I often find a soup tastes much better the second day.

Only difference in prepapration for me, was frying the garlic and onion in the olive oil, then adding herbs and spices then chicken until it turned white, then adding water. Let it cook for maybe 40 mins before I added everything else and brought it to the boil; just let it simmer away for another 40 mins.

My wife thinks I should do it the next time we have friends - I say why share! Ha ha. Great tasty meal in itself!

text:
I made this tonight for dinner and it was great.  I did everything exactly as the recipe said only I used 4 chicken breasts and fresh parsley since I was out of dried parsley.  Even with the chicken cut in half, it was still plenty for the normal recipe.  This also made a TON of soup...I ended up freezing most of it afterwards.  I topped my bowl with shredded cheddar, an extra scoop of sour cream and some tortilla chips!  Excellent...will make this again!  

*Also I used the full amount of chilli powder and my b/f and I both agree that it wasn't spicy at all.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is incredible! By far the best soup i have ever had. I was a little hesitant about adding the corn and sour cream, but it complimented the soup very nicely, and definetly should not be omitted! Also, being in the middle of july,the only corn i had was corn on the cob. I ended up par-boiling a cob of corn in the chicken broth with the chicken during the last few minutes of simmering, then cut if off the cob when i shredded the chicken. The corn finished cooking while it simmered with the final ingredients, and was an extra sweet touch. I cant get enough of this soup!

country:
None
text:
I'm not a great cook, not even close. I've been using Allrecipes for the past two years to find simple, basic recipes that even I can't screw up. I've tried some and liked them, tried others and hated them. But this recipe is above and beyond my favorite- so easy to make, and tastes SO GOOD. I follow the directions almost exactly, with one change- for the canned tomatoes, I use cans of hot Rotel. I also use hot salsa. And hot chili beans. We love spicy food in my family, and by using spicier ingredients, it makes this soup so perfect for us. Alternatively, if you can't stand spicy food, just get mild versions of all ingredients! The only real "work" in this comes from trimming/halving the chicken breasts, and then dicing one onion. I have a can of pre-minced garlic that I use for this because I don't even trust myself to chop garlic. Regardless, this soup has come out perfectly every time and the leftovers never last long. 5 stars.

I made it the crock pot way, closely following the suggestion of LasVegas00, including the pico de gallo for salsa, halving the recipe, but also adding the beans she left out & adding 2 cups of water (instead of the 2 quarts per recipe). Ate the soup without any sour cream, as I forgot about that due to my haste to sample. One word: YUM!

text:
I been looking for a good tortilla soup and I came across this one and this was the EXACT SOUP MY TASTE BUDS WANTED!  I love this soup!  I have made it over 5 times since I found the recipe 3 months ago.  I did skip the sour cream in the soup, I add it to my personal bowl if I feel like it, but it is superb without it.  I don't add the can of whole tomatoes, I just add another can of diced tomatoes, I really love tomatoes so the more the merrier.  I also only use two chicken breasts because that is enough chicken for me.  I also usually use all the water from the boiled chickens not just 5 cups.  One more thing I add is one to two small cans of green chilies, I have had the soup with them and without them and it is good both ways, I just like green chilies.  I freeze a bunch of it and it's the same goodness from when u first make it!

text:
This is my favorite soup recipe.  I have been making it for several years and it is a hit with the whole family.  Perfect for those cold winter days.  I use three cans of diced tomatoes instead of 2 cans of diced and one can of whole tomatoes because I thought the whole tomatoes were too big.  I also use 1 1/2 to 2 tablespoons of chili powder instead of 3 because my family doesn't like super spicy foods.  I think it is better if it cooks longer than 30 minutes to get it thoroughly heated through and let the flavors mix. Top with cheese and crushed tortilla chips. Absolutely delicious!

text:
Great recipe. I made it with ingredients that I had on hand and had to make two substitutions.  Tomato sauce for the condensed soup and black beans for chili beans. I had medium salsa on hand and it turned out to be the perfect amount of spice for us. Excellent! It makes a lot of soup, enough for many meals for the two of us.  Instead of freezing extra portions like I usually do, I took it to work to share with my staff.  They all liked it a much as my husband and I did.  Definitely a keeper.

text:
I absolutely LOVE this soup! I've made it about a dozen times. Now that I'm a spicy chicken veteran, I've figured out a few changes that really make the recipe POP! I substitute black beans for chili beans, add some cilantro and squeeze in the juice of a half a lime. I use rotisserie chicken from the store to save time. And to save calories, I garnish with plain greek yogurt, instead of sour cream. I also add a few dashes of hot sauce, to ensure this "spicy" soup stands up to its name. It's a rare rainy day in LA - so I'm planning to make it again tonight!

text:
We LOVE this soup!  This has become a staple in our house and even though the ingredient list is long, most (if not all) items are things I keep on hand.  I follow the recipe except for a couple of minor changes.....I use frozen corn instead of canned, and we dollop the sour cream into our bowls instead of mixing it into the entire batch of soup.  My family likes to add shredded cheddar cheese and crushed tortilla chips or fritos into their bowls at the table.  But the soup is delicious without it too.  Also, this recipe makes a ton of soup....find it hard to believe it is only 8 servings.  When I serve it to my family of 6, we have more leftover than was eaten.  Of course, that is a good problem to have.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a very simple cook, so the list of ingredients was a little overwhelming at first.  While there are quite a few ingredients, most of them are common household groceries and are relatively inexpensive.  And even though there are a number of ingredients, it's virtually impossible to mess this recipe up.  It's totally worth the time and money you spend on it.  On an added note:  If you have trouble finding CONDENSED TOMATO SOUP in the grocery store [like I did], I found a substitution online for 8oz tomato sauce, 2 tbsp sugar, 1 tbsp cornstarch, and 1/2 tsp salt.  Throw that together, and it comes out just as delicious.  I hope everyone enjoys this recipe as much as I did.  The beauty of it is that whether you're a salty, sweet, or spicy lover, you can adjust all of the ingredients exactly to your liking, and it's virtually impossible to end up with a bad result.  I promise you and your family will love this meal, and it will make plenty of leftovers that re-heat wonderfully!  Bon Apetit!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The family loves this soup!  You can omit the olive oil without effect.  I never add the sour cream into the soup, but offer it as a garnish.  The parsley can be subbed with cilantro if you like.  It's flexible, but so good.  Also, one of the cans of diced is good to sub with Hunt's chili seasoned diced tomatoes.  Then you don't even need the salsa.  Sooo good!

text:
Best soup I've ever had.  Every one else says the same.  My wife's new favorite meal.  Stay away from adding lime like some tortilla soups call for.  It detracts from the taste.  Garnish with cheese, tortilla chips, and avacado.  The chips are a must...have chips on the side and add them as you eat it so they are crispy.  Otherwise you just get a bowl of soggy chips.

text:
I didn't have tomato soup, so I used a small can of tomato sauce and a can of tomato paste to substitute.  I used 2 cans of kidney beans instead of chili beans.  I also didn't have any whole tomatoes so I used one 28 oz. can of diced tomatoes and one 15oz can of diced tomatoes with green chilis.  I omitted the chili powder altogether as the medium salsa I used made the soup pleasantly spicy but not too spicy for kids.  I also used about 2x the sour cream the recipe called for.  It was excellent. Thanks for sharing.

text:
Excellent!  I didn't read all the reviews, so I don't know how many people mention this, but the Cook time is WRONG on this.  The first thing you do is simmer the chicken for 1 HOUR! The simmer the combined soup for another 30 min.  Just wanted everyone to know that this isn't a quick soup.  And you can tell - VERY TASTY!  I used a mild salsa for my first time, but will try medium next time.  We like it hot and my dad was adding Tabasco with the mild salsa.  Shredding the chicken was so easy and I like that in soup better than chunks.  Thanks!!

None
text:
Absolutely loved this one with a few changes. I left out the can of whole tomatoes and tomato soup. I used 2 lbs chicken thighs, shredded. I also added one 15oz can of black beans (drained), 2 fresh jalapeños (diced), half a green pepper, 2 roma tomatoes (diced). I used a habanero lime salsa that I really enjoy.   I garnished with tortillas brushed with olive oil and sprinkled with fresh cracked pepper and creole seasoning and baked for 10 minutes at 350. Cut in quarters and sprinkled with cheddar cheese and a generous dollop of sour cream.  When I do this recipe again, I will add 1 or 2 habanero peppers, and maybe some diced green chilis but I am extremely happy with it. A tasty, inexpensive dinner that will make great left-overs.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! I made a very large batch, and it still didn't last as long as I expected simply because we couldn't keep out of it. I made a few alterations. First, I added  a bit of extra chicken broth since I'm cooking at a high altitude and the additional liquid helps make up for evaporation. We didn't have onion powder in the house, so I used an extra half cup of finely diced onion. I also used only canned diced tomatoes instead of canned diced and canned whole, and I added a can of black beans for color and volume. I also used plain fat-free yogurt instead of sour cream and cut back significantly on the olive oil to keep the fat content down. The finished product turned out fantastic, and I'll definitely be making it again.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Very good, I will make this again!  However, I changed it up a bit as others recommended. I used 1 can of diced tomatos, and 1 can of Hot Rotel (w/Habanero). Omitted the whole tomatos, and also used 1 can of chili beans, and 1 can of black beans. I didn't use the water from the boiled chicken, I substituted that with 5 cups of chicken broth. I also used 2 11oz cans of Mexicorn, and left out the sour cream. I added the sour cream to my bowl afterwards.   I might try hot chili beans next time instead of medium, just for a little more kick...

11/5/09 Update: This also works very well for Quesadillas. Simply drain as much of the liquid out of the soup as you can, then heat the mixture before adding to your Quesadilla with whatever other filling you may like. I just use shreddeed Chihuahua cheese. When served with sour cream for dipping, this is another way to enjoy this delicious recipe! Try it, I dare you... I bet you'll enjoy it! Hmmm, bet it would also make a great filling for Burittos, or Enchiladas that way too.

city:

region:

country:

text:
This is the amazingly the best chicken soup I've ever made or tasted - I wish there were more than 5 stars!  It's like a perfect mix between chicken chili and chicken tortilla soup.  The best part about it is that I have almost all of the ingredients on hand, it can be really healthy, and is filling!  My friend's loved it and asked for the recipe.  I followed the recipe as stated with a few minor changes:  I followed all of the measurements for the chicken broth with the addition of a small bay leaf.  It had the perfect amount of seasoning and would be great in any recipe that calls for chicken broth - so this is a keeper.  Then, the rest of the ingredients that incorportate the "soup": I used a can of diced tomato w/jalepeno (rotel) in place of the can of whole tomato.  I also added a packet of sazon and a few squeezes of Sriracha hot chili sauce to the mix for an extra kick.  I used no fat sour cream and it still tasted fantastic in this dish.  I will be making this often and next time I will also add black beans.  I dont think that there is a way that you can mess this recipe up - I've tasted the mix even before I added my own "tweeks" and it was still wonderful.

I love this recipe!  So easy.  I have made as written and it was great.  Another time I just substituted diced tomatoes for whole and omitted sour cream from pot but used on an individual basis. If you leave out the sour cream, you are talking about 420 calories for 3-4 cups of soup (1 serving).

text:
Great recipe.  I used chicken that I had previously cooked and added all of the spices that were to go into the broth.  Let cook for a short time and then added all the other ingredients.  The only other thing I changed was added 2 cans of seasoned tomatoes instead of the plain ones and added a 28 Oz. can of chopped tomatoes instead of whole.  My husband said it was the best soup I had made.  I definately will make it again.

Soooo good!  Me and my picky husband each ate two bowls of it!  I sauteed the onion & fresh garlic, then added the chx & dry seasoning (replcd chili powder w/ southwest ssn b/c I was out) & cooked til no longer pink.  Then I added the rest of the ingred and simmered for about an hour.  I also threw in diced red bell pepper and chunks of fresh zucchini from the garden.  I might add a can of black beans next time.  Served w/ french bread & butter.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved this.  As another reviewer suggested, made the tortilla strips to go along with it.  Only had 3 bouillon cubes, so added 2 TBSP poultry seasoning to the water that just covered the 8 chicken breast halves and cooked 20 minutes.  While they were cooling, sauteed the onion and garlic till soft and clear; then added a jar of Newman's black bean and corn salsa, can of petite diced tomatoes, can of tomato soup and 2 cans of spicy chili beans.  Cut up the chicken and added along with the broth and about 10 ounces drained yogurt.  It was a very healthy hit at the family gathering!

Display Name:
BETTYH88

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Adjusted this for the crockpot, and it came out nicely. Saute onion and garlic in the olive oil ,reduce the water to 1.5 cups, add a can of beer. Add all ingredients including whole chicken breasts (can be frozen or thawed) and cook on low all day, then take out chicken and shred it. Mix shredded chicken back in soup along with the sour cream, cook for a half hour on high. I also added fresh cilantro and 1.5 tsp cumin, and omitted the cans of tomato soup and whole tomatoes. Quite good topped with shredded cheese and crushed tortilla chips.

text:
Yummy!  I love the chicken tortilla soup at Panera, and since there is no Panera in my current town (a tragedy in its own right, but probably one that saves me money), I was looking for a good spicy chicken soup recipe.  This one is different than Panera's, but still tasty.  I like that it's pretty adaptable--different veggies or different beans would all taste great.  I don't care for tomatoes, so I left out all of them (except the soup), and it still tasted great, though it was probably a bit more brothy-looking than it might have been otherwise.  But it has great flavor, and that's the most important part!

text:
My husband's marine buddies came in for a weekend. I thought something hearty would be good for these "manly men."  they loved it. It makes tons, so I took the leftovers to work. Everyone loved it and wanted the recipe.   I hate the people that leave comments about changing the recipes, but I have to say this... It calls for a lot of chicken. the next time I make this I will use 1/2 of the chicken the recipe calls for. It was not "soupy" enough. I also would either use chopped canned tomatoes instead of the whole. I also added other mexican seasonings to taste. Cumin, cilantro, mexican chili powder ect.   I am rating this a 4. I am my own critic and I didnt like the soup at all. However, EVERYONE ELSE LOVES IT!

text:
Yum!! I made a few delicious and easy alterations. I sauteed the chicken with onions and peppers (cut into fajita like strips) with the garlic and dry herbs until a little blackened like fajitas. In another pan i mixed 1 can of black beans (undrained), 1 can of corn, and 2 cans rotel diced tomatos with chiles. I didn't have tomato soup, so I used a can of enchilada sauce instead. Then added the fajita mix to the soup and wala! Cheese, green onions and chips on top make it superb!

so good! this recipe will be permanently magnetized to my fridge for easy access. I took chef 101's advice and cooked the chicken with onions & garlic then added herbs & spices and finally the canned goods (using only one can of tomato and frozen corn instead of canned). It turns out rather thick - more like a chicken chili. I suppose broth could be added if someone wanted it more soup-like, but it's so perfect without. So easy! and Amazing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/125459.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is fantastic!  I have made this recipe 8 times over the past year and I love it every time!  A couple things I change every time:
- Always leave out the condensed soup, makes it taste like it came from a can!
- add a jalapeno pepper or other hot seasonal pepper from the garden, it is called "spicy" after all!
lastly, something I struggle with time and time again, I've done it with and without, but just so you all know -- it tastes just as amazing without the sour cream and lowers those calories like you wouldn't believe!  If you are going to use it, go full-throttle b/c the low fat & fat free versions texturize the soup and make it slightly strange.  Everyone loves it, add what you have in the kitchen or garden, leave out what you don't have.   This is my all time go-to recipe for potlucks, company, and just to impress the family!

text:
We LOVED this soup!  It was fabulous and authentic tasting.  There's only two of us eating this so I just used 2 chicken breasts, half a jar of Pace salsa, one can of diced tomatoes, one can of black beans, half a bag of frozen corn, a proportionate amount of the seasonings in the recipe and eye-balled how much broth to add.  I think it might have been about 3 1/2 cups.  Altogether it made enough for at least 6 servings!  And we're glad there was so much leftover because it is WONDERFUL the next day.  I found the spiciness to be perfect.  It wasn't offensive to my husband who doesn't like his food hot but it left a pleasant heat in the back of the throat as it went down.  I love this recipe and I intend to share it with everyone I know who loves to cook!

text:
I scaled it down to 3 servings and it was enough for me and my boyfriends dinner that night, lunch the next day and a little in the freezer. It comes out to be a ton! 
for the broth, I substituted chicken broth for the bouillons, added 2 cloves minced garlic for the powder, dried minced onions for the powder and no salt. Also 2 chicken breasts is way enough. For 3 servings I only put 2/3 canned beans, 1 14oz diced tomato, 7 oz frozen corn, 1/2 of the salsa, and left out the soup, whole tomatos, and sour cream. 
Turned out great, and tastes better each time its reheated!

text:
Great recipe.  My husband and I liked it alot.  I made it all in one pot except for cooking the onions and garlic in a skillet with the olive oil.  I thought it was going to be very spicy with all the chili powder but it wasn't.  I used 2 cans of roasted tomatoes with garlic and skipped the cans of whole tomaoes.  I substituted cannelini beans for the chili beans listed.  Also added a tablespoon of sugar to cut the acid of all the tomatoe ingredients.  Think I will add a little cayenne pepper next time to kick it up a bit.

This soup was so good the night of and the next day! I made a few changes as I did not have all the ingredients. For the tomatoes, I used one can of diced tomatoes and 2 cans of stewed tomatoes (which I cut up to smaller pieces). For the beans I used one can of kidney beans and one can of plack beans. I also used 4 frozen chicken breasts instead of 8 and it was plenty! Next time I would also add okra. We served with tortilla chips on top - very tasty! It had the perfect amount of spice but may be too spicy for some. Will make many more times!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!From my experience, and after reading other reviews, this recipe allows for many adjustments to personal tastes. It's a very forgiving recipe if you don't have an ingredient or two, which was what happened with me today. I was *hoping* to cut down the recipe a tad bit by only using 5 chicken tenderloins, 4 c. water, 1 can diced tomatoes, 1 can stewed tomatoes, 1 4.5 oz can diced green chiles (my husband ate the salsa), 1 can corn, 1 can light red kidney beans, 1 can mild chili beans, 1 can tomato soup and some sour cream. The spices and seasonings are also easily adjusted- I ended up adding more boullion, cayenne pepper, seasoned salt, and black pepper. Although I love the soup with the sour cream in it- next time I think I'll either use less or just add it to the top. Like other reviewers, I sauted my onion and garlic first in EVOO, then added my chicken and simmered for about 45 minutes. Overall, very good and easily adjustable to desired level of spiciness.

We also aren't fans of the whole tomatoes so we use 3 cans of diced tomoatoes with green chiles.  It is one of the best recipes I have found.

The fact that we, very amateur cooks, could make this and it turned our divine is a testament to how amazing this recipe is. We couldn't get enough of it. And knowing it was healthy made it taste even better (although it's very hard to believe how healthy it is since it tastes so good). Maybe that's a very amateur thing to say. But not sure how they added anything except that they looked pretty. We also cut this recipe down to 3 servings and it fed my very hungry fiancé and I with enough for one serving of leftovers. THANKS FOR THIS RECIPE!

text:
Mmm!  We were munching on this one for days!  I made a few changes, however:  I used 1 28oz can of Muir Glen Fire Roasted tomatoes instead of the 2 cans diced/one can whole; I used "fresh" salsa in a tub from the grocery; I topped the finished soup with sour cream instead of mixing it in; I used 1/2 package of Trader Joe's Fire Roasted corn instead of the canned corn; about 1 cup of cooked rice, which I tossed in near the end to warm it up; 1 drained and washed can of regular black beans; and used chicken stock instead of the buillon, which I didn't have on hand.  It freezes and refrigerates well and for a house of 2, we were able to stretch this for work-lunches and sides for dinner for about a week without getting tired of it.  Too yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good soup!  It took a little more work to shred the chicken than I expected, ended up needing to cut and shred simultaneously.  I didn't have onion powder, for some reason, so I used minced onion and it worked well.  I transferred the chicken out, shredded it, and put it in another bowl ... then poured the chicken stock into a measuring cup, used the same pot for browning the garlic a little (didn't have to use oil at all that way) and transferred everything back so I didn't dirty another big pot (I have to hand clean those and I am a little lazy).  We ended up with 10 - 2 1/2 cup servings.  Froze most of it in individual servings (thaws well in microwave).  There is a LOT of chicken in this soup - makes it very satisfying!  My husband topped his soup with cheese (shredded sharp cheddar) and I with sour cream, just yummy!  There is even enough leftover chicken stock to make a squash soup or something!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This makes a LOT of soup. The recipe says 8 servings, but it's probably more like 20+. 

Half a batch feeds my family for a week... happily.

Spice level was not super spicy. Perfect for us.

This is a hearty soup. Almost like stew. Save all extra broth to add for folks who can’t get enough of the liquidity part of the soup.

Be sure to make extra, it reheats great.

I am NOT a cook and only dabble in making my own food.  But after ordering out one too many pizzas I wanted to make food for the family at home.  I'm also kind of picky taste wise.  I substituted black beans for the beans in the recipe because I'm not a bean eater but i will tolerate black beans in burritos.  This was pretty labor intensive for me but very very easy to follow.  And the family liked what Dad made.....score!  I'd highly recommend this.  I'd also like to know if anybody has made it and froze the leftovers.  Can this be put in the freezer?

text:
I've made this soup for years. I make it slightly different after making it for so long. I now drop a cooked Rotisserie chicken from the grocery store into the broth instead of the 8 chicken breast halves. I leave it in the broth for 15 minutes boiling and then remove it and shred it and then add it and the broth to the mix. It saves a lot of time and still tastes super yummy!

text:
Whenever  I   buy  a whole roasted chicken there is a lot left over.  I stumbled upon this recipe and noted that I had most of the ingredients   on hand.  I was out of garlic and simply  used garlic salt  For  lack of tomato soup I used the entire can of peeled tomatoes.  Instead of chili beans I used black beans.  Since the chicken was already cooked I reduced the cooking time to 30 minutes.  Didn't add salt until I tasted it.  I topped each serving with  Kraft Mexican  grated cheese, a dollop of  sour cream and a few drops  of hot sauce.  Day's  later  my wife and daughter  are still raving about it.

This was really good!  However, I omitted the tomato soup, doubled the corn (personal preference) and added 2 Tbsp cumin, 1 Tbsp oregano and about 1/2 Tbsp each of onion and garlic powder. text:
Amazing soup! My boyfriend and I made it one night and he absolutely loved it. Has just the right amount of kick to it due to the chili powder. Due to how we were strapped for time, I cut up the chicken in cubes (added a bit of salt and pepper) and cooked them in the pan--this is so much faster if you do not have precooked chicken on you and don't want to spend too much time on cooking. I also cut down on the amount of onion by about half, and cut up I think two cloves of garlic instead, plus did not include the garlic power (personal preference). Overall, this was very tasty and I will definitely be making this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent soup - we love spicy foods and this one hit a home run.  I try to leave out as much salt as possible in recipes, so I did make the following changes:  Used 5 c. unsalted chicken broth (instead of water/chicken bouillon) as 2 qts of water was  too much; used 2 cans Rotel no salt added tomatoes/green chilies, 1 can no salt added tomato sauce instead of soup, skipped the whole tomatoes and used frozen white corn (canned corn has salt too).  I found Bush pinto/kidney chili beans combo had lower salt than regular kidney chili beans.  I diced my chicken and did step 1.  In step two, I just added everything into a crockpot on low for 6-8 hours and it was delicious.  Using the crockpot to simmer always helps the flavors go through the food so much better.  I definitely will make again and have shared with my friends.

text:
I don't make homemade  soup often, but I love this one and make it fairly often.  I cut the recipe in half and use a whole rotisserie chicken, 2 cans of diced tomatoes (one with either roasted tomatoes or mild chilies), 32 oz of gluten free tomato soup, the salsa, beans, garlic, onions (I skip the corn).  It turns out like a stew and it's great with tortilla "scoops".  I'm sure I could thin it with some broth, but I like it thick.  I can prep it in the crockpot or on the stove depending on the day's schedule.

I made this with four chicken breasts and two boneless thighs. It's certainly plenty of chicken, but I like a lot of meat in soups. userID:

Display Name:
Kirthi H
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mom used to make this soup back when I was a sophomore in high school. Now, as a sophomore in college, I've made it! The only thing that I don't like about this soup is that it has high sodium content that's very difficult to avoid. I omit the bouillon cubes, and it still tastes great. I also only use one can of diced tomatoes, chicken legs instead of breasts as they are cheaper, omit corn, and use one can of chili beans. You honestly don't need more than this. Using legs does take a lot more time though, since you have to separate it. You need a lot more time than you think to make this soup.
Review:
Rating:

userID:
6218836
Display Name:
lily.alvarez
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
115
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/548109.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a 6 quart Dutch oven for this recipe. Here is what I did and turned out amazing. 

I let the Dutch oven heat on medium high for about two minutes. Added about 3 Tablespoons of olive oil, add one whole chopped yellow onion with two table spoons of minced garlic. Once translucent, I added three large diced chicken breast pieces. Half way cooked through I added the spices for the meat to cook into adding the parsley as well, onion powder (salt and pepper to taste!).I added 1 can diced tomatoes (not 2) and about half of the whole tomatoe can and one condensed soup. Use hot pace salsa not medium for that kick! Once all sauces have been combined into the pot I followed with 1.25 cups of chicken broth NOT water. Let boil on high for about 5 - 10 minutes and simmered for about 30 minutes low to let the sour cream get creamy with soup texture. We added some more sour cream on top with tortilla crisps. Goes great with grilled cheese! My husband was hesitant about soup for dinner but loved it so much.

text:
This soup really is spectacular! I can very easily see myself making this over and over again. I made a few changes to the recipe, some based off of other reviews and some on my own personal tastes. I replaced the diced tomatoes with Ro-Tel and the tomato soup with Mexican tomato sauce. Canned whole tomatoes were ditched entirely. I'm of the opinion that the spicier something is, the better, so I also added a chopped jalapeño into the soup.

text:
Used eight chicken tenders and about eight cups water. All recipe spices. About 20 min. Makes awesome broth/poached chicken. Half onion, 3 cloves garlic, 1 1/2 tbls chili powder, large can tomatoes, all the broth, frozen corn and about a cup of homemade Pico. One can dark red kidney beans, no sour cream. Topped with shredded cheddar and tortilla strips. 8 corn, sprayed with Pam, one inch strips,400* 10 min. Still a bit spicy for kids. Would like rotel with habanero for adults.

Display Name:
Mrs. Peterson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1355912.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
At my house we love tasting food from around the world, and this is a take on the Mexican tortilla soup. I made small changes, I seasoned the chicken rather than putting the seasoning and it separate in the water, I find it holds the seasonings flavor better. Instead of 3 cloves of garlic I used about 3 tablespoons of minced garlic, didn't need the 2(14.5 oz) can peeled and diced tomatoes,I only used 1 can. used cayenne pepper since I didn't have chili pepper, and instead of chili beans I used 1 can of red beans. Topped it off with shredded sharp cheddar cheese, sour cream, scallions, and broken up pieces of tortilla chips(Which I forgot to add in my pic!)This was so excellent because of the those different types of flavors!! My Husband, kids and other relatives loved it very much. It was suppose to last 2 nights and was mostly done by the first day. Has been added to my collection of favorite comfort soups, Well make this again soon.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
2471206
Display Name:
Rhea
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Was very excited to try this recipe as a base and change to suit our tastebuds...Did not add whole tomatoes or tomato soup as I felt it would overpower the taste of the soup. I did however want to bulk up the soup. I added 2 carrots, half a punnet of white mushrooms and 3 potatoes. Did not have parsley so I used sage instead. Hubby does not like bean so hence could not add those. The recipe did not state whether the salsa should be hot or not so I opted for hot and used 1.5 tablespoons of chili powder and 1 tablespoon of masala. O and we love having the bones so i used a braai pack instead. Personally I think that using the bones added to the flavor when boiling. I loved the way the reserved juices cut the tartness of the salsa to bring a perfect blend of tart and spicy and added depth to the flavor base. I added tons of Cilantro and bought Greek Yogurt to top but the smell was so inviting that we forgot to add it. Will maybe try it tonight with the leftovers. Will definitely do this again!!!

text:
Amazing soup! I made it a little easier - instead of boiling the chicken I chopped it up and cooked until almost done and then added the onions and cooked a bit longer and then added everything else. Instead of the 5 cups of broth I just added 1-2 cups of water and it came out perfect. You could leave out the water and have it be more like a chili. I made this for work and everyone loved it.

This was delicious!  I made it exactly as written but halved the chili powder since 3 TB seemed liked a lot.  It was perfect.  I also didn't add the sour cream or shredded cheese until dishing the soup in bowls.  I will say it made WAY more than 8 servings.  We had enough for probably 12 people.  I just froze the extra.  Terrific recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tastes like chicken chili, but does taste good if you're in the mood for chili.  Certainly is a different take on chicken soup.  My family liked it and I've added it to my recipe box for occasional use. I made it as written but reduced the amount of liquid by 2 cups since my pot seemed to be getting too watery. I agree with another reviewer that it would be great over rice, as a gumbo, if you don't add the broth.  I did taste it before adding the broth and found it tasted very good.  For the next time I will not add the broth or whole tomatoes to reduce the very tomatoey flavor and serve the sour cream on the side just to limit calories. Although not a 5 star rating, certainly an overall thumbs up.  Just a minor point, my prep and cooking time took a full 1 1/2 hours.  Don't see how it could be done in much less time. thanks

text:
I used most of the basic ingredients of this recipe. On top of that, I prepared it in the crockpot. Since I was preparing it for two adults and our two yr old, I had to adjust the servings. 2 cups water and cooked the chicken and seasonings for 90 mins, took the chicken out to shred, placed the rest of the ingredients, salsa, tomato soup, diced tomatoes, and chicken into the pot for the remaining time left. After coming in from the SNOW and COLD, this was right on time to warm us up. Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
This stuff is amazing! Followed the recipe pretty closely, but I probably added a little extra chicken and chicken broth, plus added a can of black beans. As some suggested, I used Ro-Tel crushed tomatoes with cilantro, etc. I only had a little parsley left so omitted that by necessity. I served crushed blue and yellow tortilla chips with it, plus yogurt or sour cream, white rice if anyone wanted it with rice, and some shredded Mexican cheese. This stuff is to-die-for! Mine made a huge batch, so it should be good for several meals. I plan to make this a regular in my household! Thanks, Catherine!

I really like this recipe. Good with cheesey garlic breadsticks. My boyfriend didn't care for the corn, and 
I don't think that would be a significant omission, although I liked it. He suggested celery instead. The only issue I had with the recipe was that it just said to use a "large pot" and didn't say what size. I figured a 6 quart pot would be just right, but I had to take out 6 cups of liquid  to make it all fit. Still really tasty and I look forward to making it again, just scaled down for 2.  I haven't tried the leftovers yet, but I bet they'll be tasty.

text:
I changed this recipe a bit due to what I could find at the store and dietary restrictions. I halved the recipe. For half the recipe, I used one medium can of tomato sauce without salt and one medium can of diced tomatoes instead of the diced, whole and souped tomatoes. I also used frozen corn and guessed on the amount and used a can of black beans rather than chili beans. I also skipped the parsley as I don't have any and omitted the sour cream. Served with tortilla chips.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really delicious!  I made it in the crock pot  - I put everything except olive oil, corn, beans and sour cream in the crock pot.  I used all the tomatoes and then poured in a little water and the rest chicken stock to fill the crock pot (leaving enough room for beans and corn).   I used about half the chicken simply because my crock pot is too small for that amount of soup.  I cooked on low for about 7 hours.  I then shredded the chicken and added the beans, sour cream (low fat) and corn and let it cook for another 2 hours or so .    I used frozen corn, pinto beans and fresh hot salsa.  I also added some cumin and extra chili powder.  In the future I will probably skip the peeled, whole tomatoes because I don't feel they add much.  This would be great with rice also.  This tastes like chili made with chicken and I love it!    Great recipe.

text:
As a mom of 5 kids who needs a easy go to soup that everyone loves, well this is it.  I have made this a dozen times and have several bags of it frozen in my freezer for this purpose I double the recipe. I add a extra can of beans or 2 because that is how my family likes it.  I do NOT add as much chili powder as suggested (the first time I did that it was way to hot for my family). I use Greek yogurt in place of the sour cream none of my family can tell the difference and it is healthier. When I do not have time to boil the chicken I use chicken broth and a few cans of chicken, not quite as tasty but will do in a pinch.  You cannot go wrong with this soup!

This was a big hit for the adults and older kids in our family, not so much for the under 5 crowd, though. We had three adults and four sons with hearty appetites, and we still had PLENTY left over.  But the leftovers were something to look forward to!

After reading the great reviews, I decided to give it a try....with some alterations.  I added all the dry ingredients with boiling the chicken(used 2 bone in chicken breasts and chicken sausage) so I can adjust the taste if need be when everything is combined. When I combined everything I added all of the broth instead of the 5 cups along with a can each of black & red beans and 1 cup tubettini pasta(I added the last 5min).  It came out awesome!!  Everyone loved it and not only do we have food the the next day but it was enough to freeze a big bowl.  Thanks Catherine!!

text:
This is SOOOO good!!  I halved the batch since it was only for my husband and I and I had a bunch for leftovers...can't wait for tomorrow!  I popped the raw chicken in a crockpot with the salsa, tomatoes, spices, etc (all except the bouillon and sour cream) and let the chicken cook for a couple hours until it was cooked through.  I took it out and shredded it and put it back in with the rest of the ingredients.  Also I only added about 1 cup of bouillon to make it thicker, added a little cheddar and topped with some spicy nacho Doritos...very yummy!!  Will definitely make again and again.

The only modifications I made were eliminating the whole tomatoes (there are plenty already), using only 6 chicken breast halves and adding the sour cream on top of our bowls of soup rather than stirring it into the whole batch. Delicious!

Freezes well and, in my opinion, is even better after freezing or sitting in the fridge for a couple of days. text:
Amazing and easy!! Tried it for the first time with some modifications (no sour cream at all; Only 1 can of diced tomatoes, not 2; I sliced 2 fresh tomatoes instead of the can of whole tomatoes; I used 1 can of chili beans, not drained, and 1 can of black beans, drained; and the 3 tablespoons of chili powder was not enough, but didn't want to add more of it so I put red pepper flakes for the extra kick I wanted). This is a really great recipe as it is pretty versatile to what you can find around your house, as long as you have the tomato and salsa base, you can just fool around with it. Awesome!

text:
This is a great recipe. A friend came over: it wasn't spicy enough for him. He felt topping it with pepper-jack cheese and adding a little bit of tabasco would have made it perfect. I think it's great as is. I made it in the crock-pot, but instead of chicken bullion, I used "Better than Bullion" (first ingredient is chicken, rather than salt) and didn't put any salt into the recipe. I also only put 1 cup of water. I'm definitely making this one again :)

text:
Very good and quite simple. The only part that really required alot of work was shredding the chicken. I made it exactly as the recipe said except letting people add their own sour cream at the table and instead of whole tomatoes I just used more of the diced ones. Then I made my own little tortilla chips from another users review suggestion. It was scrumptious! There is alot of chicken in the recipe. It could probably be halved if someone wanted to but with as much as there was in it, it was very filling. Will definitely make again but would be nice to use pre shredded chicken on lazy days. Not sure it would have that perfect flavor as it does with boiling in the juices of this recipe.

text:
After reading several reviews, I followed some advice to make a great soup. I only used 4 chicken breasts and skipped the whole tomatoes. I reduced the chili powder to 2 tablespoons, but kicked up the heat with 2 cans of tomatoes with green chilies. This made the soup quite spicy - perhaps too much for some people! I used one can of red beans and one can of white beans. The sour cream adds a nice touch at the end and gives the soup a nice color. I'm taking the big pot to a church dinner tomorrow.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this soup. I marinated my chicken breast over night. I changed the recipe just a little. I added pigeon peas in addition to the red kidney beans. I also omitted the sour cream. lastly, I used skinless chicken breast with the bone. I love when meat cooks until it falls off the bone. Once the chicken was fully cooked, it just slid off the bone and then I shredded the chicken using two forks. Some additional seasoning that I used: Cayenne Pepper, Garlic Salt, Bay Leaves and Seasoned Salt. This helped to make a delicious chicken broth!

I think this is a great soup for the cold season. My son is starting to show signs of a cold, he doesn't like spicy food, but this is going to be the perfect medicine for him and help with that ugly cough.

text:
This soup is awesome! It's like a creamy chicken chili soup! It had a perfect spiciness to it and I'm not a spicy foods kinda girl. It just had a little heat to it that was perfect! I accidentally doubled the sour cream. It said one container of sour cream and I didn't notice that it had (8 oz.) next to it. But it still turned out awesome! My boyfriend hates sour cream and he loved it! (I didn't tell him there was sour cream in it :) ) Anyway, my only complaint was that there were so many big chunks of tomato. My boyfriend and I don't like big chunks of tomato so next time I'll leave them out or just use one can and dice them smaller. All in all, superb and will definitely make again!

text:
I gave this four stars because I completely changed the recipe.  I did not want it to be too tomatoey so I only used a large can of chopped tomatoes and one can of Rotel.  Those are the only tomato products that I used.  I used one can of chili beans and one can of corn.  I cut corn tortilla's from the grocery store into strips with a pizza cutter and deep fried them until they were crisp and added a little salt.  These turned out much better than Tostito's or some other tortilla chip.  My picky 7 year actually gave this recipe a 100 on a scale of 1 to 5.  I think that sums it.  Beware, you may have to add your own blend of seasonings to season this recipe to your taste.  I added seasoned salt and old bay until it tasted good to me.
Review:
Rating:
3

text:
I've made this recipe many times and I enjoy it every time!  I do make some changes though.  I don't use as many tomatoes as suggested in the original recipe.  If I put in the whole tomatoes and the tomato soup, then I don't use the diced tomatoes.    Sometimes I just use the salsa and only one other tomato product, and this recipe is still just as good.  Instead of using chili beans, I use a can of rinsed and drained black beans.  Also I don't add in all the chicken broth - I like this soup kind of thick.  In addition, instead of mixing the sour cream into the soup, I place a dollop on top of the soup when it's being served.  This is a great soup and my friends at work enjoy it when I bring in this dish!  This one's a keeper!

text:
My wife and I had a great time making this soup on a Saturday afternoon.  We are not into chunky soups too much so we blended the onion, tomatoes, and salsa which created a slightly thinner soup.  We cooked some white rice and put about a tablespoon in each individual bowl, which everyone loved.  This makes a tremendous amount of soup (maybe 20 bowls?) so be prepared to freeze a portion.  It is spicy, but not overly so.  Our kids loved it topped with tortilla chips and cheddar cheese.  This is one of the best soups we have ever made, or tried for that matter - highly recommended!

text:
I was pretty skeptical about this recipe...but it is GREAT!! My boyfriend and I were pleasantly surprised, and impressed! I did make several changes. I baked seasoned chicken breasts (375 degrees F) in a cake pan with a little butter, olive oil, and water covered with tin foil. I combined all the ingredients in a crockpot while the chicken was baking. I used one, drained 28oz can of petite diced tomatoes instead of all three cans, I used half mild salsa and half jalapeno salsa (very spicy!), and used some of the broth from the chicken's cake pan to thin it out a little. To be honest, this soup is still simmering in the crockpot...but based on "taste tests," it is awesome! I cannot wait to add cheese, chips, and a little chopped, raw onion! Thank you so much!

text:
I thought this soup was very good, and my husband loved it.  I made a couple changes.  I only made 1/2 the recipe, and I used Frozen Chicken Tenderloins.  I didn't defrost them, just put them right in the pot, and they cooked up in about 45 minutes.  I also added a green pepper to the mix while I was cooking the onion too.  I used frozen corn instead of canned.  I used a can of Tomatoes and Chilis instead of the regular cannned chopped tomatoes.  The last thing I did was at the end I tasted it, and it seemed it needed some extra kick, so I added about 8 shakes of the Tabasco sauce, and some juice from the jar of Jalapenos that I had in the fridge.  My husband raved about this, and had two big soup bowls full!

text:
I thought this soup was going to be amazing with all of the five star ratings, but I found it to be bland. I think the recipe calls for too much chicken because I used about 3/4 of what the recipe calls for and my husband even commented that there was a lot of chicken. It also wasn't salty enough. I also think that it was too watery. Maybe omitting the whole peeled tomatoes next time would be best. Anyway, I'm thinking that maybe a lot of the flavor is dependent on what salsa you use and I just didn't use the right kind. Overall it was ok, but not great.

text:
Oh, the flavor!  Rich and velvety and with just the perfect level of spiciness.  The only changes I made were to leave out the whole tomatoes and use a rotisserie chicken instead of  boiling breast-halves in the stock.  I won't be doing that again--the boiling of the breast-halves would actually be less work, I think.  The rotisserie chicken, which was cooked perfectly and tender, ended up having a mealy texture and almost disintegrating into the soup.  Regardless, it was delicious, so I will most definitely be making this soup again.

None
text:
This soup is great!  It makes A LOT of soup and there is just two of us, but it warms up wonderfully for lunches.  I made this the "easy" way by sweating the onions and garlic in the oil, chopping the chicken breasts into large pieces and sauteeing for a minute, then adding the canned ingredients.  I let it simmer for quite a while and then pulled the chicken pieces out to cool.  The easiest way to shred that I've found is to use your fingers and pull them apart.  It's super quick and easy.
